July 27th, 2023 ( Gates of Vienna — Delivered by Newstex )

A federal judge in Delaware ordered Hunter Biden to look for a job and stay off the dope if he wants to avoid jail time. These instructions were given to Mr. Biden after his sweetheart plea deal fell through. There's no word yet on whether the judge would find it acceptable for Mr. Biden to take a job on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.

In other news, Russia has increased the duties imposed on imported European wines and Norwegian seafood.

To see the headlines and the articles, click 'Continue reading' below.

Thanks to Dean, Diana West , DV, LP, Reader from Chicago, Roger, SS, and all the other tipsters who sent these in.

Notice to tipsters: Please don't submit extensive excerpts from articles that have been posted behind a subscription firewall, or are otherwise under copyright protection.

Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rates by Quarter Point to Combat Inflation

The Federal Reserve Bank on Wednesday raised interest rates by a quarter of a point in an effort to fight inflation, putting its key interest rate of 5.5% at its highest level in 22 years.

While the Fed maintained interest rates last month after 10 straight hikes, the new target federal funds rate is in the range of 5.25% to 5.5%. The previous range set in May was 5%-5.25%.

The Fed's goal is to move inflation to 2%, and the Consumer Price Index Report for June showed that inflation is at 3%.

The findings are detailed in a new report dubbed 'Little Red Classrooms,' which was sent to 34 governors, key lawmakers and committee chairs on Wednesday.

'The alarming evidence uncovered by our investigation should concern parents, educators, and policymakers alike. Families deserve to know who is influencing the American education system so that they can make informed choices about what their children are learning behind closed doors,' PDE president Nicole Neily told Fox News Digital.

Crane Atop Manhattan Skyscraper Partially Collapses After Catching Fire; 5 Hurt

A crane on top of a Manhattan skyscraper partially collapsed after it broke out in flames, sending black smoke billowing into the air more than 40 stories above the ground, video showed.

The crane was on a building on Tenth Avenue between West 41st and 42nd streets in Hell's Kitchen, according to city officials, just a few blocks from Times Square. Crews received a call about a fire in the engine compartment of the crane just before 7:30 a.m.

As they were en route to the scene, the arm of the crane collapsed, fire officials said. Video showed the outermost portion of the crane striking a building across the street, sending debris flying. Then the arm slammed into the tower before plummeted down onto scaffolding and the street below, sending people running.

'The top part of the crane, the boom, and a 16-ton load crashed to the ground,' said FDNY Deputy Commissioner Joseph Pfeifer.

Democrats Run the Most Crime Ridden Cities in the US — But is the Situation Even Worse Than We're Told?

In the past year we have been seeing a lot of news stories stating something like this: 'More Americans believe crime is up in their city, but public perception doesn't always match reality.'

However, is the problem really public perception? Or is it the manner in which crime data is being collected? The FBI's data collection is generally considered the most complete and accurate look at crime in the US and is referenced consistently by the media and by political leaders, but what if that information is now unreliable?

Downtown Baltimore Grapples With Plummeting Property Values Amid Urban Exodus

'The property values are declining rather rapidly,' said Economist Anirban Basu, President of the Sage Policy Group.

'The only way for Baltimore to get out of this quandary is to grow its tax base, to add taxpayers, not subtract from that,' said Basu.

Dropping Oppenheimer's Bomb Was Strategically and Morally Wrong

by Diana West

When I was a syndicated columnist, various editors urged me to write a few seasonal 'evergreens' that might be published when I wanted to take a break. I never pulled it off — there was always something brand new to write about. I realize now that the following 2015 essay about Hiroshima really fits the bill.

The version below was originally updated for 2016. I am running it again today, old chestnut-style, in the wake of the release of 'Oppenheimer' (about which I will soon have more to say); and also in reply to a piece of fake-narrative-enforcement published today by the Time magazine mockingbirds, who have trotted out Evan Thomas (or vice versa) to deny the FACT that Japan tried repeatedly to surrender to the United States long before the A-bomb was dropped, tested, or even fully developed.

Why were peace feelers from Japan crushed? The same reason peace feelers from Germany were crushed. As I document in American Betrayal, stealth communist agents and ideologues inside governing Allied (and Axis) councils made it their mission to ensure that WWII would not end too soon for the purposes of their masters in Moscow; that war would continue on into its most savage and destructive final years in order to allow the Soviet Union the necessary time to fight its way into Europe — and, in the Pacific Theater, into China (for five days), where more communist agents and actors would later ensure the demonization and betrayal Chiang kai-Shek and the enthronement of world-super-killer Chairman Mao.

Evan Thomas, by the way, is the grandson of Norman Thomas, six-time Socialist Party presidential candidate, who is quoted several times in American Betrayal :

1953: 'Here in America more mea sures once praised or denounced as socialist have been adopted than once I should have thought possible short of a Socialist victory at the polls.'

1958: 'The United States is making greater strides toward socialism under Eisenhower than even under Roosevelt.'

1962: 'The difference between Democrats and Republicans is: Demo crats have accepted the ideas of socialism cheerfully, while Republicans have accepted them reluctantly.'

And now, to the Evergreen

FBI Carried Out Warrantless Monitoring on Man Who Posted Guns for Sale on Facebook

Authored by Emily Miller via The Epoch Times (emphasis ours)

A Texas man who posted on Facebook that he was selling his own guns was placed under warrantless surveillance by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF). The ATF investigated the man, found no evidence, yet gave his information to the FBI to monitor him for at least six months.

According to internal documents reviewed by The Epoch Times, two ATF special agents interviewed the Hispanic man who admitted to 'advertising' his personal firearms for sale on Facebook. He stated that he had a 'habit' of purchasing new guns, tinkering with them, losing interest, and subsequently selling them. The man told the agents that he never made a profit.

'I kept waiting for the part where ATF identified something illegal, and it never came,' Eric Olson, a lawyer for Gun Owners of America (GOA) told The Epoch Times.

The idea of using AI to detect and perhaps even censor AI content online has been growing over the last year. However, if recent tests are to be believed, the accuracy of such technology is far from perfect — meaning genuine content could be falsely censored if such technology is trusted.

Sturbridge Woman Who Survived Car Explosion Was Trying to Get High, Police Say

A woman walked away from a car explosion in Sturbridge on Saturday with only minor injuries, but a preliminary investigation found that the incident may have been caused by an attempt to get high, according to authorities.

On Saturday at around 3:49 p.m., the Sturbridge fire department received a 911 call for a possible vehicle explosion at 110 Charlton Road, near a Walmart, Sturbridge police and fire officials said on Facebook. A black Toyota Corolla was found with all the windows blown out, with all four doors displaced but still attached to the car.

A woman from inside the car was treated with minor injuries, officials said. She refused to be taken to a nearby hospital for further treatment.

While the investigation into what happened is ongoing, the Sturbridge Police Department's early findings indicate the woman may have kept all the windows initially closed while huffing cans of compressed air before lighting a cigarette.

'Huffing is a type of substance abuse that involves inhaling fumes from household substances in order to experience a high,' according to the American Addiction Centers.

The centers added that 'Spray paint and other paints are commonly used in huffing. Some of the toxic chemicals in paint provide an intense high that can be easily obtained by those who are otherwise unable to afford or get access to other drugs. However, huffing paint and other forms of inhalant abuse are extremely dangerous, causing multiple severe injuries and deaths every year.'

Brussels Terror Trial: Six Convicted of Murder

After 18 days of deliberations, late Tuesday, July 25th, a Belgian jury found six suspects guilty of their involvement in the March 22nd, 2016 attacks on Brussels' airport and a metro station, Belgian media report.

As per Belgian law, their sentences will be determined in a second part of the trial, starting on September 4th. Except for the Farisi brothers, most of the remaining accused face life in prison.

The convictions mark the conclusion of the largest trial in Belgium's judicial history, which, having started in early December, lasted a total of seven months.

France: Driver Attacked by Mob, Kidnapped After Collision With Dirt Bike

A motorist who collided with a dirt bike in France was subsequently attacked by a mob of people who demanded he give them thousands of dollars before kidnapping him last week, according to reports.

The horrifying incident unfolded on Saturday evening in Melun, a commune in the department of Seine-et-Marne.

French Intelligence Knew of Wagner Mutiny Plans — l'Opinion

French security officials knew in advance about Wagner private military company chief Evgeny Prigozhin's mutiny plans, the l'Opinion newspaper claimed on Wednesday.

According to the outlet, the General Directorate of External Security of France (DGSE) has long monitored the activities of the Russian PMC because of its allegedly 'anti-French' activities in Africa, including in the Central African Republic and Mali, which is why they were aware of Prigozhin's plans before mid-June.

L'Opinion's sources also said that France had discovered Prigozhin's plan even before it was known to the CIA, which also claims to have been aware of the move in advance. CIA Director William Burns previously stated that Prigozhin's actions 'did not come as a surprise' to Washington.

The Wagner mutiny began on June 23, when Prigozhin accused the Russian military of launching a deadly missile strike on one of the group's field camps. The Russian Defense Ministry denied the allegation, but Prigozhin vowed to march to Moscow and demand 'justice.' The uprising was ultimately halted after Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announced that a deal had been reached with the PMC after consultations with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The group, along with Prigozhin, has since relocated to Belarus, where it has begun providing training to Belarusian troops and sharing its battlefield experience gained from the Ukraine conflict.

Germany: Leading Regional CDU Politicians Call for AfD 'Firewall' to be Torn Down

As scores of Germans flock to the AfD, viewing it—rightly or wrongly—as the only party that articulates and offers solutions to the increasingly and exceedingly grim realities faced by working and middle-class people, the CDU is undergoing rightward reshuffling, with more and more top politicians calling for the AfD firewall to be disassembled.

Lawmakers in the state of Thuringia—a conservative, anti-globalist stronghold where, according to the latest polls, one in three support the AfD—are perhaps most acutely aware, compared to those in other regions, that if the CDU wishes to show its voters that it's not just another woke-left-liberal party and to have the chance to govern again, cooperation with AfD is essential.

Germany: Anti-Semitism Among Muslims More Widespread Than Among the Rest of the Population

A large majority of Germans firmly reject anti-Semitic statements. A study by the Konrad Adenauer Foundation found this out. However, such attitudes are more widespread among Muslims than among the general population.

Anti-Semitic attitudes are more widespread among Muslims than among the rest of the population. This is the result of a study by the CDU-affiliated Konrad Adenauer Foundation, which is available to the Evangelical Press Service (epd). According to this, four percent of the population on average agree with the statement that Jews are 'sneaky'. Among Muslims, approval was twelve percent.

Around a quarter (26 percent) of Muslims agree with the statement that rich Jews are 'the real rulers of the world' (population average: six percent). Seven percent accept violence against Jews (population average: two percent).

Germany: Group Rape in Berlin's Gorlitzer Park

In the largest park of Berlin, Görlitzer Park, there have been eight serious crimes committed from January to the end of June. The police are still investigating four suspects (aged 14-19) in connection with sexual assaults. According to BILD, this is not the only incident this summer; there was also a group rape in Görlitzer Park!

German Association Leaders Tell Mainstream Parties to Up Their Game Amid Voting Surge Toward Right-Wing AfD

German business associations are concerned at the meteoric rise of the right-wing Alternative for Germany (AfD) party, which for months now has consistently been polling higher than the governing SPD and the Green party.

'We need to engage much more with dissatisfied citizens,' the Confederation of German Employers' Associations (BDA) told German newspaper Die Welt.

In view of the AfD's popularity, Germany's employers and the skilled trades are urging the other parties to pursue policies to attract those disillusioned with modern society and return them to the center ground.

Hungary Will Defy EU to Defend Its Farmers Against Ukrainian Grain

Hungarian Agriculture Minister Istvan Nagy said in Brussels on Tuesday that Budapest will protect the interests of its farmers by any means and at all costs, even if the European Union does not extend the EU ban on imports of Ukrainian grain after Sept. 15

'We must insist that the measure be maintained, as we cannot allow Hungarian reservoirs to be refilled with Ukrainian stocks,' he stressed.

'The measure must be extended until after the harvest to make room for our own harvest. If no Ukrainian grain arrives in the country, there will be room for Hungarian crops,' Nagy said.

He said the Black Sea ports are closed, and the extension of the grain agreement has failed, meaning that the Russian side will not agree to deliver grain by sea. If the 40 million tons of Ukrainian grain reaches the EU's internal market, traditional European agriculture will collapse, he warned.

Poland's Military Aid for Ukraine Exceeds €3 Billion

Around €500 million worth of equipment is to be sent to Ukraine in the next three months, and Polish government officials reported it had already provided more than €2.5 billion from donating Leopard tanks, MIG-29 fighter jets, 240 T-72 tanks, 54 Krab howitzers, and a multitude of other equipment and ammunition.

Rebellion Among French Police is Growing

Discontent within the French police force has swollen since the riots that accompanied the death of young Nahel. Law enforcement feels let down by political authorities, and a protest movement—that began in Marseille after a police officer was detained on suspicion of violence—is spreading throughout the country.

On the night of July 1st, just a few days after Nahel was killed by a police officer in Nanterre, a 22-year-old boy called Hedi was beaten unconscious in the streets of Marseille. On Thursday, July 20th, four police officers from the BAC (Brigade Anti Criminelle) were charged with assaulting the young man. One of them was placed in pre-trial detention—a decision that sparked strong protests within the police force, and prompted Frdric Veaux, the director general of the police, to call for his release. 'Knowing that he is in prison keeps me awake at night,' he declared on Sunday, July 23rd. On Twitter, the director general of the police received the support of Paris police prefect Laurent Nunez. Interior Minister Grald Darmanin also took a stand in support of the police, assuring the director general of 'all his support.'

Spain: Inconclusive Vote Leaves All Options Open in Forming a New Government

Political deadlock continues in Spain three days after voters failed to give right-wing parties a majority to form a working coalition in an election that saw a surprising rebound for Spain's ruling socialist party PSOE and its leader Pedro Sanchez.

Despite substantially increasing both their vote share and parliamentary representation, the conservative Partido Popular (PP) did not collect the 175 seats required in the SpanishCongress of Deputies to form a coalition, as their potential populist partners VOX lost almost half of their existing seats in a shocking turn of events.

While facing a potential challenge to his leadership within his own party, PP leader Alberto Feijóo has broached the possibility of a deal with the PSOE despite previously running on a platform to remove Sanchez from office.

The country's Security Service issued a statement on Wednesday stating that it is 'actively managing persistent attack threats targeting Sweden and Swedish interests.' The nation's terror threat level remains at an 'elevated' three out of a possible five points.

Sweden's reputation as an accepting nation has been tainted by false information campaigns, wrongly painting it as a nation 'opposed to Islam and Muslims, where acts against Muslims are state-sanctioned, and where social services can abduct Muslim children,' said the officials.

Swiss Study: Heart Injuries From COVID Vaccine 3000x Higher Than Thought

It is a small study, but a very disturbing one.

We keep being told that injury to the heart from the COVID vaccine is very rare, but a study done in Basel Switzerland indicates that the rate of subclinical myocarditis after the COVID vaccine is hardly rare at all.

In fact, in a study with only 777 participants with a median age of 37 — all medical professionals getting the COVID vaccine—the incidence of elevated cardiac enzymes 3 days after injection was pretty substantial, at almost 3%.

The CDC did a study and from that, they claimed the rate was 0.001%, or one out of 100,000.

2.8% is a lot higher than 0.001%. Another 0.3% had 'probable myocarditis,' putting the total at over 3%. That is 3000 times higher than the US government claimed.

Andrew Beaton, 59, said his family were 'lucky' to escape after the bike, bought online for his son last Christmas , burst into flames while charging under the stairs.

The blaze ripped through his Lancaster home at astonishing speed, momentarily trapping his wife and daughter upstairs and gutting the entire property within minutes.

'It took the fire brigade four or five minutes, that's all, and the house had gone,' he told Sky News.

'It was that intense. I've never seen fire move so quick.'

Dearlove, who headed MI6 between 1999 and 2004, revealed that analysis of Covid shows that it started as a naturally occurring bat virus that had been 'mucked around with' by virologists to be 'highly infectious' among humans.

African Leaders Arrive in Russia for Summit as Kremlin Seeks Allies Amid Fighting in Ukraine

ST. PETERSBURG, Russia (AP) — Some African leaders arrived in Russia on Wednesday for a summit with President Vladimir Putin as the Kremlin seeks more allies amid the fighting in Ukraine.

Putin has billed the two-day summit that opens Thursday in St. Petersburg as a major event that would help bolster ties with a continent of 1.3 billion people that is increasingly assertive on the global stage.

On Wednesday, Putin met separately with Ethiopia's Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, and said Russia will more than triple the number of Ethiopian students it hosts and cover their education costs.

Later in the day, Putin is set to hold talks with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi.

EU Looks to Shoulder Burden of Ensuring Ukraine Grain Exports

Ukraine is among the world's top three grain exporters and is popularly known as the 'breadbasket of Europe.'

Following last week's pullout by Russia of the Black Sea grain deal, under which Ukraine was allowed to move its crops through the Black Sea, Ukraine's grain storage facilities at the Ukrainian ports of Odesa and Chornomorsk, as well as its ports on the Danube River, have been deemed valid targets by Moscow.

The Ukrainian State Bureau of Investigations (SBI)—the law enforcement agency tasked with investigating and prosecuting crimes committed by public officials, abuse of power, and embezzlement—earlier this week arrested a military official on corruption charges after he amassed a small fortune by helping men evade mobilization.

Yevhen Borisov, head of the Territorial Center for Procurement and Social Protection in Odesa, an agency that oversees mobilization and conscription efforts in the southern oblast, was arrested on Monday, June 24th, on charges of illegal enrichment, dereliction of duty, and deliberate evasion of military duty, Radio Svoboda reports.

The charges follow an investigation launched last year that revealed Borisov had purchased real estate in Spain and luxury vehicles, all registered in his mother's name, worth some 4 million euros, with money he had amassed via a scheme where he accepted bribes in return for exempting some would-be soldiers from mobilization.

President Zelensky Hails Progress Made in Construction of Ukraine's Drone Army

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced on Tuesday that his country is making progress in building its own 'drone army' and has recently stepped up drone attacks in Crimea and on Russian territory.

In a video address on Tuesday evening, President Zelensky told his compatriots that he had attended a private event on Tuesday where government officials presented the results of the first year of the drone army. 'It is not a project, but a real Ukrainian drone army,' Zelensky stressed.

Russia Moves Attacks on Ukraine Grain to Danube Ports

Russia has continued to target Ukrainian grain after pulling out of the Black Sea grain agreement on July 17th.

Ukrainian officials said 15 Iranian-made Shahed-136 drones were launched at warehouses on the Danube River in the ports of Reni and Izmail on Monday night, July 24th.

Six people were wounded in the attacks that were the latest in an escalation of bombings of Ukrainian infrastructure and a series of grain-related exchanges between the two countries.

Russia Increases Age of Military Conscription to 30 Amid War in Ukraine

Russia has legally increased the age for military conscription to 30 years old in a bid to bolster its ranks amid the ongoing war in Ukraine.

With little talk of peace negotiations between the West and Moscow for the proxy war being waged in Ukraine, Russia's State Duma, the lower house of the Federal Assembly, passed a bill on Tuesday allowing for the government to conscript men up to the age of 30, state media news agency TASS reported.

The Black Sea Grain Initiative collapsing last week, meaning there is no longer a safe corridor for Ukrainian grain exports by sea, has seen a shift in Russian military posture says the United Kingdom, predicting the coming of a full-on blockade.

WSJ: The West Knew Ukraine Wasn't Prepared for Counter-Offensive, Hoped Their 'Courage and Resourcefulness Would Carry the Day'

The report reads: 'When Ukraine launched its big counteroffensive this spring, Western military officials knew Kyiv didn't have all the training or weapons—from shells to warplanes—that it needed to dislodge Russian forces. But they hoped Ukrainian courage and resourcefulness would carry the day. They Haven't.'

All it takes to traverse vast minefields is a bit of courage and resourcefulness!

Departure of Chinese FM Qin Gang Viewed With Relief by EU

Chinese state media ended weeks of speculation as it confirmed Tuesday afternoon that the country's foreign minister Qin Gang had been ousted in favour of his predecessor Wang Yi.

Qin only took up the role in December last year and his conspicuous absence from diplomatic events had attracted international attention in recent weeks amid rumours of an internal CCP palace coup against him.

Chinese officials had previously stated that Qin was too ill to carry out his duties before both the CCP's Standing Committee and Politburo rubber-stamped his departure Monday.

Russia Seeks to Strengthen Military Ties With North Korea

Russia is looking to further strengthen its relationship with North Korea after having effectively broken off all diplomatic ties with the West following the invasion of Ukraine. Moscow officials will visit Pyongyang this week, alongside a delegation from Beijing, to mark the 70th anniversary of the end of the Korean War.

Russia's defence ministry has been open about its intention to use the trip for its benefit, hoping to increase its military ties with the East Asian nation. In a statement, it said:

This visit will help strengthen Russian-North Korean military ties and will be an important stage in the development of cooperation between the two countries.

Unprecedented Decline: Japan's Population Decreases by Nearly 800,000 Across All Prefectures for the First Time

In 2022, Japan faced an unprecedented demographic challenge as all of its 47 prefectures experienced a population decline.

The nation's total population decreased by almost 800,000 individuals, setting two unwelcome records. This worrying trend, however, is not unique to Japan, as many other countries are also heading towards uncharted territory in terms of demographics, as The Guardian reported.

Japan's Prime Minister acknowledged the severity of the situation and vowed to address the crisis. Despite this commitment, national policies have so far been unsuccessful in curbing the population decline. Nevertheless, a few small towns' concentrated efforts have shown some positive impact.

Recently released data revealed that deaths reached a record high, surpassing 1.56 million, while the number of births in Japan plummeted to just 771,000 in 2022. This marked the first time the number of newborns fell below 800,000 since records began.

Even with an all-time high increase in foreign residents, which exceeded 10% and totaled 2.99 million, the overall population decline persisted for the 14th consecutive year, reaching 122.42 million in 2022.

Why Australians Are Paying So Much for Gas — Despite the Country Being One of the World's Largest Exporters of the Energy Source

Australians pay more than double the price for natural gas that Americans do despite both nations being exporters leading with energy expert saying a lack of competition drives big local profits.

Terrorism Escalates in West Africa: 2023 Mid-Year Report Reveals Over 1,800 Attacks

According to a top regional authority, over 1,800 incidents of terrorism have occurred in West Africa in the first half of 2023, leading to nearly 4,600 fatalities and severe humanitarian effects.

Omar Touray, President of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Commission, addressed the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday, highlighting the harrowing results of these insecurities.

Exclusive: Illegal Migrants — A Pan-European Issue: Italian Senator Roberto Rampi Calls on EU to Unite

In 2023, Italy faced a record influx of illegal migrants. According to the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, Frontex, the number of cases of illegal border crossings along the central Mediterranean route increased by 137% to 65,571.

Germany: CSU Demands Compulsory Work for Asylum Seekers Receiving Benefits

The demand by the Union parties for an obligation to work for asylum seekers has provoked backlash.

The clumsy attempt by the CSU to go for votes only reveals their desperation,' commented the deputy leader of the FDP parliamentary group in the Bundestag, Christoph Meyer, on the initiative, according to the Bild newspaper. urn:contentItem:68RF-DWB1-JCS1-61GB-00000-00Revolve Group Inc at William Blair Growth Stock Conference - Final2023-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:09:08ZLexisNexis060723a15586978.778Revolve Group Inc at William Blair Growth Stock Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Jesse Timmermans

Revolve Group, Inc. - CFO

Conference Call Participants

* Dylan Carden

William Blair & Company - Analyst

Presentation

DYLAN CARDEN, ANALYST, WILLIAM BLAIR & COMPANY: My name is Dylan Carden. I'm the analyst here that covers Revolve. We're great -- we're pleased today to have Jesse Timmermans, CFO. You want to take it away?

JESSE TIMMERMANS, CFO, REVOLVE GROUP, INC.: Yeah.

DYLAN CARDEN: Great. Thanks, everyone.

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Thanks, Dylan. I will jump in. I know it sounds like some of you are generalists here. So I'll take it a step further beyond what Dylan communicated earlier to me is that we sell clothes online, pretty simple. But it's way more complicated than that and complicated in an exciting way.

I'm going to pause here just a second on the intro slide. This is actually AI-generated image. We'll get into AI and technology here in a minute, but we're pretty excited about this campaign heading into Revolve Festival this past month during April and a lot of good stuff going on the AI front.

So if you step back, we're actually celebrating our 20th year anniversary this year. So we've been around a while. Mike and Michael founded the company 20 years ago, not fashion guys. So they relied on data and technology to actually create Revolve. And it's based on, like I said, data and technology, data-driven merchandising combined with a powerful marketing engine.

And that's important. You can have the powerful marketing, the social media marketing, but without the great merchandise, it doesn't -- it's not as impactful. And on the flip side too, you can have the great merchandise. But if you don't have that authentic connection with this next-generation consumer, not as impactful.

We have a global reach. Just shy of 20% of our sales are to customers outside of the US, and that's a growing market for us, huge TAM. Again, we've been doing this for 20 years. We've been profitable every year, except for 2008 in the great financial crisis.

And that gets back to the founder-led entrepreneurial culture. Mike and Michael actually bootstrapped the company through the financial crisis, only took our first funding in 2012, went public actually four years ago today.

Strong balance sheet, again, consistently profitable over time and growing in a large market. And if you look at the market, we are squarely positioned between two really significant shifts that are happening right now, e-commerce, which has been happening, that continues to grow. We expect that to continue to grow, and the brick-and-mortar share shifting to e-commerce over time.

And then we have purchasing power of this next-generation consumer, and that's shifting to this next-generation consumer over time. And it's important because she shops differently. She's digital, social, engaged. She wants discovery; she wants newness.

And I say she -- 97% of our sales are to the millennial female. We'll get into men's and some of the other growth opportunities in a minute, but it is primarily female focused destination at this point.

We serve her through two complementary destinations. We say complementary because they are unique and different, but also complementary in primarily the product assortment and the price point. Revolve is the lion's share of the business, 84%. You can see the AOV there of $279.

This is primarily dresses, going-out apparel. It's kind of that festival this summer expanding into categories such as active and outerwear and cold weather gear, different from our historical summer spring festival. I think if you rewind a few years, you would run into a customer on the street and she would say I love Revolve. I'm going to a party this weekend or I'm going to festival, and I got my dress there.

We used to think that was a great compliment. Now it's almost a kind of a constructive criticism because we want her to say I love Revolve because I go for my dress for festival, for active, for beauty, for my significant other, which is what we're working on and a huge growth opportunity for us.

Complemented with Forward, this is the higher-end luxury destination. And complementary in that it is a different price point and it SKUs more handbags and shoes than dresses. We know that if she's buying a $200 dress, she's complementing that with a multi-thousand-dollar handbag, statement pair of shoes, something unique and special from Ford. You can see the different brand assortments here.

Revolve is the emerging and established brands, but primarily emerging. We have about 20% of the Revolve business as our own brands that we design and develop in-house. We call them owned brands, not private label, because they are true brands in the eyes of the consumer. These are kind of knockoff lower price point brands.

And then the luxury brands from the Forward destination. And forward really differentiated from the traditional luxury players and that curation and that young luxury feel. If you compare it to a, say a Farfetch, which, if you know what you want, you go to Farfetch because they have everything under the sun.

My Theresa, great operators, but a little bit kind of older school, older style luxury versus the Kendall Jenner West Coast, have young luxury feel with a lot of more emerging brands combined with those established brands.

Customer service and focus on that customer has been core to the business since day one. Combined with the data-driven merchandising that I mentioned at first, Mike and Michael treated the home as a addressing room from day one. They were trying to create the biggest, the best, the most curated department store online. And in order to replicate that experience, they knew you have to have free shipping and free returns.

And on top of that, just fast, everything fast, accurate, great customer experience. All of our fulfillment is 1P, or customer service is 1P. So really controlling everything soup-to-nuts on that customer experience. And that comes through.

We'll get into retention and the customer dynamics here in a bit, but you can see the record NPS score increasing over time. And that develops this really trusted relationship with her. So she comes back more frequently over time. And also, buys at higher average order values.

Again, 20-year anniversary, long track record of profitable growth. Profitable growth is the key. We're very capital efficient, which leads to a strong balance sheet. You can see the 22% three-year CAGR here.

We did have a dip during COVID. We're all about going out, living your best life. So when COVID hit, of course, everything was put on hold for us. We had to shift pretty quickly and abruptly into the COVID categories like active and home and beauty and things like that versus the dresses that we are known for.

And then when COVID was over, just as abruptly shifting back into dresses and going on. You can see the recovery there. Again, consistently profitable.

And taking share over time. You can see that here, Revolve versus the industry e-commerce growth benchmark where we outperform every year, again, except for that COVID year.

I mentioned capital efficiency. CapEx is generally, call it less than 1% of net sales. Here we have some peaks and valleys, but it's generally consistent over time, which leads to a really strong balance sheet. We ended the quarter last quarter with $283 million in cash.

We had strong positive free cash flow in the quarter. And that really stands out when you look at the peer group here, with the growth in profitability and cash flow with really just Revolve. And then we have Zalando here as well.

But really important, especially in a macro environment that we're in today, where strong balance sheet, cash is king. We can stay front-footed on the marketing and technology investments where others are forced to pull back and make their own decision for the long term.

We're getting into customers here a little bit. Active customers at 2.3 million -- billion -- yeah, 2.3 million, sorry. And they buy at full price.

Again, she comes to us for discovery, for what's new, what's exciting. She's not coming to us for the price or for a discount. And with that strong customer service, she comes back to us more frequently over time.

Our revenue retention is over 100%. If you look at year two and beyond. If you blend the year one and year two, you can see the retention of the pre-existing coordinate sales here. COVID dipped down to 74%. Of course, we had a strong rebound to get to 120%, and then even last year was 97% revenue retention. So again, a really strong customer dynamic.

You can see the stacks of the cohorts on this slide, which really hit home. And again, we have 20 years of cohorts, really consistent behavior from those customers. And really back to the customer service, the data-driven merchandising, really the core of what Revolve is.

And the customers. Here's a good visual of the activity of those customers, the number of orders placed per active customer. Active customer, to clarify, is the trailing 12-month numbers if you look at the active customers versus the orders placed over the last 12 months.

Over 3.5 orders per active customer, which is down from that COVID recovery period of 2021, but still higher than our pre-COVID levels. So again, showing that activity over time. And we think we can increase that activity, and also, the net sales per active customer increasing over time.

Our pre-existing customers, because of that frequency and that retention rate, active customers -- 50% of our active customers are pre-existing customers. That 50% makes up 77% of the orders and 79% of the net sales. So there, you can see that 50% punches above their weight on the orders and then even more so on the net sales, showing both the frequency increase and the average order value increase over time.

If we look at the most recent quarter, very challenging times. It was a mixed quarter for us. Starting with the positive on the left here. Number one priority going into the quarter was to right size our inventory kind of rewind to COVID. We pulled back significantly. We reassorted into those stay-at-home COVID categories.

When the world opened up again, we reassorted in and pivoted back into the dresses, chase demand. And then around mid-year, May, June of last year when the economy started to slow down, we had to pull back. We were over-inventoried like many others out there.

Number one priority leaving 2022 and into 2023 was to right size that inventory. We think we're on track and had a really successful quarter in bringing that inventory back into check, which results in $48 million of free cash flow. That's two times that of the full year of 2022, primarily because of that inventory dynamic and really bringing things back in check.

On the more challenging side. It is tough out there. The consumer sentiment is low, consumers challenge. She is making decisions between that dress and paying for gas and paying for rent and all the other inflationary costs out there. So we ended the quarter at minus 1% that led into April, which was minus 7%.

And then most recently, this past month of May, we were down mid-single digits. So the pressure has continued to really saw progressively more challenging quarter as the quarter progressed in Q1, where typically, we see March 120% that of January.

This year, March was actually lower than January, which is very atypical for our seasonality where we see a build into that spring and summer season and festival and that going out time. So very challenging time, I think both from a demand perspective and just her sentiment.

And then also on the cost perspective. Costs are higher. Inflation is real. Return rates for us are up year on year and then over a multiyear period as well.

There are some longer-term dynamics at play there. But also, just the consumer shift where she is more and more comfortable returning coming out of COVID, she was more comfortable returning. And then when we see these abrupt macro shifts, we do see an increase in that return rate.

The increase in return rate has a meaningful impact on the cost structure, which resulted in still positive adjusted EBITDA about a 5.4% margin, which was down year over year. We have a lot of things in the works to bring that back to the double digits, but it's going to take some time to work through that, both on the return rate front, inflationary costs working through this cycle, but confident in the long term.

And with the strong balance sheet, we're confident we're making the right decisions now to benefit us over the long term and not pulling back in the wrong areas.

I mentioned inventory that was number one priority coming into the quarter, rightsizing inventory. So you can just see the visual here where that differential between the net sales growth and the inventory growth has significantly compressed from the, call it the trough of Q2 '22.

And looking -- I mentioned, making the right investments for the long term and having a strong balance sheet and allowing us to do that through these kind of disjointed times. I think we are founded in a down cycle in that dot-com bust of 2000 -- just after the 2001, 2002. We bootstrapped through the great financial crisis.

I think if you ask Mike and Michael living through that and operating through that, we came out stronger. So I'll use the analogy that Mike uses and that this is like a forest fire where it weeds out all that small brush and only the stronger left standing. And we feel the same today.

With the stronger balance sheet, we're even more confident. So we're able to invest. Continue on the marketing, we are launching a forward pop-up tomorrow. Yeah, tomorrow is a kind of private opening night for that. This is one of the larger forward-dedicated brand marketing investments we've made to date.

This is a pop-up shop in in LA curated by Kendall Jenner, our Creative Director, both from an aesthetic perspective and then also the brands that we're going to carry there. So it's one store and then also place for events. So we'll have multiple events throughout the course of that pop-up shop.

Also, a test into accepting returns in a physical location, what does that do to the customer experience. One of our initiatives is to increase the cross-shopping between that Revolve customer and the FWRD customer. Again, we know if she's buying that $200 dress, she's buying handbag, why not at FWRD?

So really cross marketing to that powerful 2.3 million active Revolve customers. So Revolve customers can actually take the returns to this forward pop-up. So doing a little bit more of that cross-marketing, cross-shopping initiative.

FWRD renew a great way to acquire new customers. This is selling pre-owned handbags on FWRD, both from a buyback perspective where we buy back the bag from an existing FWRD customer, and also curating other third-party authenticated handbags that maybe it's a brand we weren't able to carry on FWRD, so it's a great way to attract that new customer into FWRD.

International is a growth initiative. We partnered with Nykaa in India to tap into that market. The Middle East and Mexico, some of those emerging markets have been the fast-growing markets for us as of recent.

And then LOBA, recent own brand launch. We're really optimistic and excited about the own brands platform over the long term. LOBA and Helsa are two of the most recent launches. These are partnerships with influencers, celebrities that have performed very well.

And then on the back office, the efficiency front. Really excited about AI. And then we have our East Coast fulfillment center that we are ramping up that will offset some of the increased costs from those returns, and also provide a better customer experience for the customers on the East Coast.

And just a quote here from Mike, our Co-Founder, in showing their ownership. So very much aligned in that. Mike and Michael, still own about 45% of the outstanding shares. So I think that entrepreneurial founder-led spirit is still here today, very active Co-CEOs and Founders in the business.

Looking ahead, the growth drivers as we cycle through this, whatever we're in and however long it takes, we do think there's this just huge opportunity in the core. So we have a lot of other growth initiatives. But even without those, we think there's opportunity in this core.

Only 3% penetrated in the target demographic. You get to that 3% in a number of ways. You can look at the number of women in the US, 18 to 44, which is our target age demographic.

You can look at our sales versus what we define as the TAM in the US, which also translates to about 3%. And because TAMS are squishy and populations are squishy, you can look at just as a gut check, look at the active customers for some of the existing players out there and how Revolve compares to that. And we continue to take share from these existing players.

The offering. I've mentioned the kind of that order frequency and how do we get her to come to us for more than just the dress and more than just the festival. Beauty is a really exciting opportunity for us, great tool for customer acquisition, lower price point. We know she is buying beauty, of course, from somewhere, why not Revolve?

We think we can curate better and different. We have her engaged. We have a great experience. It's around 3% of our sales now. If you look at comparables out there, we think it can be more than 10% of the business over time.

Just hired a dedicated beauty director that is -- number one, acquiring brands. That's the first step in beauty. It's to acquire the brands, get the right assortment on the website, then work on the experience. And this is similar to what we did for FWRD, similar to what we do for international when we're going through growth initiatives. So one, get the product; two, get the experience, right? And then really start to market the product to the customer.

Men's and other opportunity, about the same size as beauty right now at about, call it low-single digits percent of the business. We carry men's across both Revolve and FWRD. So another great cross-shopping opportunity.

We also know that the female -- typically, 30% to 50% of the purchases for the male come from a female. We have a very captive and engaged female audience. So we see a lot of opportunity in men's. Also, not really anybody out there really curating men's and providing a really great destination for that male in the way we think we can and then actively use as an example of other adjacent categories that we can expand into.

Beauty, just a quick chart there to show the opportunity. And I guess I should go back to the cross-shopping. I mentioned the cross-shopping opportunity between Revolve and FWRD. We think we can tap that two point -- the vast majority of that 2.3 million active customers on Revolve and sell FWRD to her.

A couple of the recent things we have done, the loyalty program that we had on Revolve, launching that on FWRD and allowing her to use her loyalty points cross platform. Updating the site nav, so that FWRD and men's are both more prominence on the site and easier to navigate between the two destinations. I mentioned the marketing that we're doing and more cross marketing between the two dedicated e-mails about FWRD to that Revolve customer.

This is more on FWRD. And then international. Internationally is just shy of 20% of the business today. Over time, we have, again, number one is get the service and the product right. Service internationally involve making that international experience more like the US customer experience where it's free shipping, free returns.

Historically, if you rewind five years ago, really painful for an international customer where you had to pay for your return. Not only did you have to pay for your return, but if you look at Canada, for example, you would be shocked at the checkout because you have these incremental Canadian taxes that you'd have to pay.

And then if you want to return the product, you need to go to the government to recollect those taxes. We wouldn't refund those taxes. So now, with all-inclusive pricing, everything's included in the price on the website. Then if you return, you get the full price returned and refunded to you and then we work with the Canadian government to recollect those taxes.

So huge improvement in the customer experience. Of course, that does increase the return rate, but more than offset by the increase in gross sales, which increases the net sales. And so, that localization started in the UK, moved into Europe, moved into Australia.

Canada was one of the more recent larger markets to launch that all-inclusive pricing and localization. Those western markets and more established markets have been more challenged recently, both from a macro perspective and then also from a currency perspective.

We price in US dollar and then convert to the local currency. So when you have a strong US dollar, you had a pricing disadvantage to the tune of 10% plus or minus in those core regions like the UK and Europe, also Australia. So those regions being challenged but offset by really great growth coming from some of our emerging regions like Mexico, China, Middle East, India.

Mexico has doubled year over year and is now one of our top five markets. And then looking ahead internationally, it's all about that customer experience. Number one, get the product right; number two, technology site enhancement, payment types. And then we can really start to market to that international customer.

Right now, we are indirectly marketing. Social media really has no boundaries outside of maybe China. So we have an international influencer base. So we are indirectly tapping into that international customer, but going in country by country and more dedicated and specific marketing to that customer to expand the share.

Own brands, huge opportunity for us in the long run. If you look back at the history of own brands, we went from 0% to 36% in five years from 2014 to 2019. That was too fast. And we became over-assorted in certain categories and price points. And V2 of the own brand is to grow that, but in a more moderated pace.

And we think we can have a more profitable own-brand business at a lower percentage of net sales than we did before. And that's going to come through a combination of new brands, also new styles and products within the existing brands expanding into additional categories.

One of the recent categories was Wellbeing and BeingWell, which is a sustainable active brand that we launched. And then also partnering with influencers, celebrities, personalities.

If you think about Helsa recent launch, that has performed very well. And unique from our own brand perspective in that Helsa was carried on both FWRD and Revolve. It kind of edited differently for each of those sites, but the product was similar. So really great launch.

And I mentioned LOBA, which was a recent launch, performing really well and really tapping more into that younger Gen Z consumer versus the millennial that's been at the core. And that is a wrap.

Questions and Answers

DYLAN CARDEN: Awesome. So we have about eight minutes here. We have a Q&A breakout at [Nager Maher] on the Midwest. But if anyone has questions now, happy to deal with.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Most outside. I think at some point -- sorry, the question was for beauty, can we expand with own brands or is it going to be third-party outside brands. At least for the start, outside third-party brands and really building out that assortment. And then over time, there is the potential for own brands, but not a focus in the near term.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: This idea of you capturing more than beyond festivals events, something that Michael talks about recently, I guess, broadly, what's the strategy there? And what have you seen from a market share or loss share perspective in your existing customer base? And you look at Nordstorm's 35 million customers and say that those are our customers hopefully over time. Is that the base condition that you expect?

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Yeah, absolutely. We see those 35 million customers as very addressable, and we continue to take share. And then you add Nordstrom plus Macy's plus Saks plus Neiman plus everybody else, we think we can continue to take share. And again, largely addressable when we expand categories, when you expand age/demographics. So that is the goal, both in that core customer, address more aspects of her wallet.

Beauty, for example, is a great way to acquire new customers. New customer is over-indexed on beauty versus the other. So it's a great price point to get her. Also, a great add-on product if she's buying the dress to throw in a beauty product.

And then I mentioned, the men's where 30% to 50% of the male purchases out there come from a female. We have this very captive and active female audience. So tapping into that.

And then just the other adjacent categories. Cold weather gear, for example, historically, it's been all about -- not all about, but skewed towards summer, spring, the festival, the dresses, the swim, the going out.

Two years ago, we started to push more on ski and ski wear. So that really curated aspirational, going to Aspen Veil Switzerland and really looking your best while you're in the lodge, while you're skiing. And that's performed really well over the last couple of years.

So more opportunity to spread the sales out across the year, tap into more aspects of her wallet, and expand the TAM via some of those other demographics.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And it involves a bit of a different [message here]. I think some people see Instagram as (inaudible). But as TikTok and other platforms emerge, it actually benefits the strategy as far as being able to reach broader audience in different aspects of their life.

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Yeah, yeah, absolutely. We feel we -- are around for 20 years, so we are around before Instagram, before Facebook. So there's -- she's always look to somebody, something, some influencer to guide her in her purchase, whether that was the fashion editor in the early days, that moved to bloggers, that moved to influencers on Instagram with a static post that shifted now more recently to video, whether video being on Instagram or on TikTok.

So we've been able to really navigate and be at the forefront of all of those shifts. And like I said, she'll always look to something or somebody before that influence. So we're confident that we can continue to shift. Where she's at we'll be at. And we'll be -- I think the key is being authentic, having the right merchandise, combined with the right marketing, whatever kind of venue or vehicle that's in.

AI, I had mentioned in the early part of the presentation that being an AI-generated image. And that permeates throughout the organization and throughout the growth strategies.

We think AI is real. It's here. We've been using AI/machine learning for years, whether that's through in the early days of inventory planning, inventory management.

That moved more recent in the last couple of years to operational things like fraud detection and loss package prediction. And now, more recently, that AI editorial campaigns, this kind of feeds into how you shift the marketing, shift the messaging, shift the product in a really quick way. So that AI image, it was a campaign, multiple models, AI generated.

With clothing, we actually took that, that clothing that was produced via AI and produce physical goods and sold that via our own brand platform to real customers. So that's the next step is, using AI for editorial, for creative, for next-step design. And just the speed of iteration that we can accomplish through AI versus the traditional processes, we're pretty excited about.

And then longer term, the site experience. And I mentioned return rate increasing. We are looking to decrease return rate, but in win-win ways for the customer and for us.

We're not going to make it harder for her and start charging for returns, shortening the window, pulling the return slip from the package. We know that if you do some of those things, return rate will increase. But it also is a negative experience for her and will impact that long-term retention that we're proud of and that benefits us over the long term.

So are there ways via technology, via AI to improve the experience for her on the site through personalization, recommendations, that's more near term. Longer term is their augmented reality, AI-generated virtual try on that to make that first purchase more educated.

I think there will always be the case where she's going to an event on Saturday. She needs a dress. She's going by five to make sure she gets the right one for that event, and we're okay with that. But it's just making that experience better and better for her.

And to the extent we can't reduce the return rate, she continues to behave in that way and buy the multiple dresses to keep that one, then offset that with cost and efficiency improvements through East Coast distribution center, through better inventory flows, and a number of other projects where we're working on.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: (inaudible) active customers, is that all individuals, or (inaudible)

JESSE TIMMERMANS: No, all individuals. Yeah, yeah. Yeah, it's a -- yeah, you mentioned rent the runway. It's all purchases and returns and individual customers, but we do have a sizable reverse logistics process given that if our $1 billion of sales and we have a 50%-plus return rates, we're actually selling $2 billion to get $1 billion returned to net to that $1 billion. So it's a pretty scaled operation.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Can you squeeze it to one minute how you're managing costs?

JESSE TIMMERMANS: One minute. Managing costs, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Why is it difficult from a marketing standpoint (inaudible)

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Number one, the premium price point helps, especially on that return rate where you have more room to absorb the cost of the returns versus operating at a lower price point and you're paying the same cost per package going in and out. So that's a benefit for us. And really, a moat is that premium price point, the premium nature of the product.

The areas we are focused on controlling costs, I guess, one is gross margin, working through that inventory, getting back to a higher full-price mix. We're confident in that. We're confident we can do that in the near term.

If you work down the P&L, the fulfillment line item, I mentioned East Coast distribution center. That is very early on, early innings. So as we grow into that space, scale efficiencies, and then also cost benefit from not shipping onesie-twosie products back and forth from the East Coast to the West Coast, but refulfilling within the East Coast.

That also impacts the selling and distribution line item where you're offsetting that return rate with those freight savings and not shipping back and forth.

Next step on the fulfillment footprint is looking at international distribution centers, small footprint, international distribution centers to do that refulfillment, or holding the returns in the region and reshipping to that customer in the region.

And then we have probably two dozen other individual initiatives against that selling and distribution line item from looking at international freight carriers and using alternative carriers, optimizing rates within existing carriers, domestically looking at line haul opportunities, and different last-mile carriers to get better freight rates there.

We're also seeing fuel surcharge start to abate. So that was a peak. Last Q2, we're starting to see a tailwind from that versus a headwind that we've been seeing for the last several years. Marketing is one where we are not calling that a cost savings. With a strong balance sheet with the strong customer that we have, we want to continue to market, continue to acquire customers.

While others are pulling back and forced to play defense, we think this is a great opportunity to really build for the future and come out stronger when we get through this cycle.

And in G&A, being around for 20 years, that's largely fixed. And we get scale efficiencies on that line item over time. And this is, again, an opportunity for us when others are pulling back and -- for example, firing engineers, we're hiring engineers. We're going more global with our technology and back-office infrastructure.

So a lot of opportunity in these kind of disjointed times.

DYLAN CARDEN: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible)

JESSE TIMMERMANS: Thanks.

DYLAN CARDEN: Thanks, everyone, for being here.
