urn:contentItem:6GTK-K4F3-RS7P-V4PJ-00000-00Revolve Group Inc (RVLV )FY 2023 Conference Call Transcript2023-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:09:08ZLexisNexisRevolve Group Inc (RVLV )FY 2023 Conference Call TranscriptCall Participants:

Jesse Timmermans -- Chief Financial Officer (RevolveGroup, Inc.)

Dylan Carden -- Analyst (William Blair)

Unidentified Participant


Presentation

Dylan Carden:

My name is Dylan Carden. I am the analyst here that covers Revolve. We're pleased today to have Jesse Timmermans, CFO. Do you want to take it away?

Jesse Timmermans:

Yeah, sure.

Dylan Carden:

Great. Thanks, everyone.

Jesse Timmermans:

Thanks, Dylan. I will jump in. I know it sounds like some of you are generalists here. So I'll take it a step further beyond what Dylan kind of communicated earlier to me, is that we sell clothes online, pretty simple. But it's way more complicated than that and complicated in an exciting way.

I'm going to pause here just a second on the intro slide. This is actually a AI-generated image. We'll get into AI and technology here in a minute, but we were pretty excited about this campaign heading into Revolve Festival this past month or in April, and a lot of good stuff going on on the AI front.

So if you step back, we're actually celebrating our 20th year anniversary this year. So we've been around a while. Mike and Michael founded the company 20 years ago, not fashion guys. So they relied on data and technology to actually kind of create revolve.

It's based on, like I said, data and technology, data-driven merchandising, combined with a powerful marketing engine. And that's important. You can have the powerful marketing, the social media marketing, but without the great merchandise, it doesn't -- it's not as impactful. And on the flip side, too, you can have the great merchandise, but if you don't have that authentic connection with this next generation consumer, you are not as impactful.

We have a global reach. Just shy of 20% of our sales are to customers outside of the US. And that's a growing market for us, huge TAM. Again, we've been doing this for 20 years. We've been profitable every year except for 2008 in the great financial crisis.

And that gets back to the founder-led, entrepreneurial culture. Mike and Michael actually bootstrapped the company through the financial crisis, only took our first funding in 2012, went public actually four years ago today. Strong balance sheet, again, consistently profitable over time and growing in a large market.

If you look at the market, we are squarely positioned between two really significant shifts that are happening right now, e-commerce, which has been happening. That continues to grow. We expect that to continue to grow and the brick and mortar share shifting to e-commerce over time. And then we have purchasing power of this next-generation consumer and that shifting to this next-generation consumer over time.

And it's important because she shops differently. She's digital, social, engaged; she wants discovery; she wants newness, and I'd say she -- 97% of our sales are to the millennial female. We'll get into men's and some of the other growth opportunities in a minute, but it is primarily a female-focused destination at this point.

We serve her through two complementary destinations. We say complementary because they are unique and different, but also complementary, in primarily the product assortment and the price point. And Revolve is the lion's share of the business, 84%. You can see the AOV there of $279. This is primarily dresses, going out apparel. You know it's kind of that festival this summer, expanding into categories such as active and outerwear and cold weather gear, different from our historical kind of the summer-spring festival.

I think if you kind of rewind a few years, we'd run into a customer on the street and she would say, I love Revolve. I'm going to a party this weekend or I'm going to a festival and I've got my dress there. We used to think that was a great compliment. Now it's almost kind of a constructive criticism because we want her to say, I love Revolve because I go for my dress for festival, for active, for beauty, for my significant other, which is what we're working on and a huge growth opportunity for us.

Complemented with Forward. This is the higher-end luxury destination, and complementary in that it is a different price point, and it skews more handbags and shoes than dresses. We know that if she's buying a $200 dress, she's complementing that with a multi-thousand dollar handbag, a statement pair of shoes, something unique and special from Forward.

You can see the different brand assortments here, and we have always emerging and established brands, but primarily emerging. We have about 20% of the Revolve businesses are own brands that we design and develop in-house. We call them own brands, not private label, because they are true brands in the eyes of the consumer. These aren't kind of knockoff lower price point brands. And then the luxury brands from the Forward destination.

And Forward really differentiated from the traditional luxury players in that curation and that kind of young luxury feel. If you compare it to say a Farfetch, which if you know what you want, you go to Farfetch because they have everything under the sun. Mytheresa, great operators, but a little bit kind of older school, older style luxury versus the Kendall Jenner, West Coast, kind of young luxury feel with a lot of -- lot more emerging brands combined with those established brands.

Customer service and focus on that customer has been core to the business since day one. Combined with the data-driven merchandising that I mentioned at first, Mike and Michael treated the home as a dressing room from day one. They were trying to create the biggest, the best, the most curated department store online, and in order to replicate that experience, they knew you have to have free shipping and free returns.

And on top of that, just fast; everything fast, accurate, great customer experience, all of our fulfillment is one P, our customer service is one P. So we're really controlling everything soup to nuts on that customer experience. And that comes through -- we'll get into retention and the customer dynamics here in a bit, but you can see the record NPS score and increasing over time. And that develops this really trusted relationship with her. So she comes back more frequently over time and also buys at higher average order values.

Again, 20-year anniversary, long track record of profitable growth. Profitable growth is the key. We're very capital efficient, which leads to a strong balance sheet. You can see the 22%, three-year CAGR here. We did have a dip during COVID. We're all about going out, living your best life. So when COVID hit, of course, everything was put on hold for us. We had to shift pretty quickly and abruptly into the COVID categories like active and kind of home and beauty and things like that versus the dresses that we are known for. And then when COVID was over, just as abruptly, shifting back into dresses and going out. And you can see the recovery there. Again, consistently profitable.

And taking share over time, you can see that here Revolve versus the industry e-commerce growth benchmark, where we outperform every year, again, except for that COVID year.

I mentioned the capital efficiency. Capex is generally, call it, less than 1% of net sales. Here we have some peaks and valleys, but it's generally consistent over time, which leads to a really strong balance sheet. We ended the quarter -- last quarter with $283 million in cash. We had strong positive free cash flow in the quarter, and that really stands out when you look at the peer group here with the growth and profitability and cash flow with really just Revolve and then you have Zalando here as well.

But really important, especially in a kind of a macro environment that we're in today where strong balance sheet, cash is king, we can stay kind of front-footed on the marketing and technology investments where others are forced to pull back and make the wrong decision for the long term.

We'll get into customers here a little bit. Active customers at 2.3 million -- billion -- yeah, 2.3 million, sorry. And they buy at full price. Again, she comes to us for a discovery, for what's new, what's exciting. She's not coming to us for the price or for a discount. And with that strong customer service, she comes back to us more frequently over time. Our revenue retention is over 100%. If you look at year two and beyond, if you blend the year one and year two, you can see the retention to the pre-existing cohort net sales here.

COVID dipped down to 74%. Of course, we had a strong rebound to get to 120%, and then even last year was 97% revenue retention. So again, a really strong customer dynamic. You can see the stacks of the cohorts on this slide, which really brings it home. And again, we have 20 years of cohorts, really consistent behavior from those customers, and really back to the customer service, the data-driven merchandising, really the core of what Revolve is.

And the customers, here is a good visual of the activity of those customers, the number of orders placed per active customer. Active customer, to clarify, is a trailing 12-month number. So if you look at the active customers versus the orders placed over the last 12 months, over three and a half orders per active customer, which is down from that COVID recovery period of 2021, but still higher than our pre-COVID level. So again, showing that activity over time. And we think we can increase that activity and also the net sales per active customer increasing over time.

Our pre-existing customers, because of that frequency and that retention rate, active customers, 50% of our active customers are pre-existing customers. That 50% makes up 77% of the orders and 79% of the net sales. So there you can see that 50% punches above their weight on the orders and then even more so on the net sales, showing both a frequency increase and the average order value increase over time.

We look at the most recent quarter, very challenging times. It was a mixed quarter for us, starting with a positive on the left here. Number one priority going into the quarter was to right-size our inventory. If you can rewind to COVID, we pulled back significantly. We reassorted into those kind of stay-at-home COVID categories. When the world opened up again, we reassorted and pivoted back into the dresses, chased demand, and then kind of around mid-year May, June of last year, when the economy started to slow down, we had to pull back, we were over-inventory like many others out there.

Number one priority kind of leaving 2022 and into 2023 was to right-size that inventory. We think we're on track and had a really successful quarter in bringing that inventory back into check, which resulted in $48 million of free cash flow. And that's two times that of the full year of 2022 primarily because of that inventory dynamic and really bringing things back in check.

On the more challenging side, it is tough out there. The consumer sentiment is low, consumer is challenged. She is making decisions between that dress and paying for gas and paying for rent and all the other inflationary costs out there. So we ended the quarter at minus 1%. That led into April, which was minus 7%. And then most recently, this past month of May, we were down mid-single digits. So the pressure has continued. We really saw a progressively more challenging quarter as the quarter progressed in Q1 where typically we see March 120% that of January. This year, March was actually lower than January, which is very atypical for our seasonality where we see a build into that spring and summer season and festival and that going out time.

So very challenging time, I think both from a demand perspective and just her sentiment. And then also on the cost perspective. Costs are higher, inflation is real, return rates for us are up year-on-year, and then over a multi-year period as well. There's some longer-term dynamics at play there, but also just a consumer shift where she is more and more comfortable returning, coming out of COVID. She was more comfortable returning. And then when we see these abrupt macro shifts, we do see an increase in that return rate.

The increase in return rate has a meaningful impact on the cost structure, which resulted in still positive adjusted EBITDA, but a 5.4% margin, which was down year-over-year. We have a lot of things in the works to bring that back to the double digits, but it's going to take some time to work through that both on the return rate front, inflationary costs, working through this cycle, but confident in the long term. And with the strong balance sheet, we're confident we're making the right decisions now to benefit us over the long term and not pulling back in the wrong areas.

I mentioned inventory. That was the number one priority coming into the quarter, right-sizing inventory. So you can just see the visual here where that differential between the net sales growth and the inventory growth has significantly compressed from the, call it, the trough of Q2 '22.

And looking -- I mentioned making the right investments for the long term and having a strong balance sheet and allowing us to do that through these kind of disjointed times. I think we are founded in a down-cycle and that dot-com burst of 2000 -- just after the 2001-2002. We bootstrapped through the great financial crisis. I think if you ask Mike and Michael and living through that and operating through that, we came out stronger. So I'll use the analogy that Mike uses in that this is kind of like a forest fire where it kind of weeds out all that small brush and only the stronger left standing.

And we feel the same today. With a stronger balance sheet, we're even more confident. So we're able to invest, continue on the marketing. We are launching a Forward pop-up tomorrow. Yeah, tomorrow is kind of private opening night for that. This is one of the larger Forward dedicated brand marketing investments we've made to date. This is a pop-up shop in LA curated by Kendall Jenner, our creative director, both from an aesthetic perspective and then also the brands that we're going to carry there. So it's one store and then also a place for events. So we'll have multiple events throughout the course of that pop-up shop.

Also a test into accepting returns in a physical location. What does that do to the customer experience? One of our initiatives is to increase the cross-shopping between that Revolve customer and the Forward customer. Again, we know if she's buying that $200 dress, she's buying a handbag, why not at Forward. So really cross-marketing to that powerful 2.3 million active Revolve customers. So Revolve customers can actually take the returns to this Forward pop-up. So doing a little bit more of that cross marketing, cross-shopping initiative.

Forward Renew, a great way to acquire new customers. This is selling pre-owned handbags on Forward, both from a buyback perspective where we buy back the bag from an existing Forward customer and also curating other third-party authenticated handbags that maybe it's a brand we weren't able to carry on Forward. So it's a great way to attract that new customer into Forward.

International is a growth initiative. We partnered with Nykaaa in India to tap into that market. The Middle East and Mexico, some of those emerging markets have been the fast-growing markets for us as of recent. And then LOBA, recent own brand launch. We're really optimistic and excited about the own brands platform over the long term. LOBA and Helsa are two of the most recent launches. These are partnerships with influencers, celebrities that have performed very well.

And then kind of on the back office, the efficiency front, really excited about AI and then we have our East Coast fulfillment center that we are ramping up that will offset some of the increased costs from those returns and also provide a better customer experience for the customers on the East Coast.

And just a quote here from Mike, our co-founder in showing their ownership, so very much aligned in that Mike and Michael still own about 45% of the outstanding share. So I think that entrepreneurial, founder-led spirit is still here today, very active co-CEOs and founders in the business.

Looking ahead, the growth drivers, as we cycle through this, whatever we're in and however long it takes, we do think there's just huge opportunity in the core. So we have a lot of other growth initiatives, but even without those, we think there's opportunity in this core. Only 3% penetrated in the target demographic. You get to that 3% in a number of ways. You can look at the number of women in the US, 18 to 44, which is our target age demographic. You can look at our sales versus what we define as the TAM in the US, which also triangulates to about 3%. And because TAMs are squishy and populations are squishy, you can look at just to kind of -- as a gut check, look at the active customers for some of the existing players out there and how Revolve compares to that. And we continue to take share from these existing players.

The offering. I mentioned the -- kind of that order frequency and how do we get her to come to us for more than just a dress and more than just the festival. Beauty is a really exciting opportunity for us, great tool for customer acquisition, lower price point. We know she's buying beauty of course from somewhere. Why not Revolve? We think we can curate better and different. We have her engaged, we have a great experience.

It's around 3% of our sales now. If you look at comparables out there, we think it can be more than 10% of the business over time. Just hired a dedicated beauty director that is -- number one, acquiring brands. That's the first step in beauty, is to acquire the brands, get the right assortment on the website, then work on the experience, and this is kind of similar to what we did for Forward, similar to what we do for international when we're going through growth initiatives. So one, get the product; two, get the experience right, and then really start to market the product to the customer.

Men's, another opportunity; about the same size as beauty right now at about, call it, low single digits percent of the business. We carry men's across both Revolve and Forward, so another great cross-shopping opportunity. We also know that the female, typically 30% to 50% of the purchases for the male come from a female. We have a very captive and engaged female audience. So we see a lot of opportunity in men's. Also not really anybody out there, really curating men's and providing a really great destination for that male in the way we think we can. And then actively using as an example of other adjacent categories that we can expand into.

Beauty, just a quick kind of chart there to show the opportunity. Oh, and I guess I should get back to the cross-shopping. I mentioned the cross-shopping opportunity between Revolve and Forward. We think we can tap that 2 point -- the vast majority of that 2.3 million active customers on Revolve and sell Forward to her.

A couple of the recent things we have done, the loyalty program that we had on Revolve, launching that on Forward and allowing her to use her loyalty points cross platform; updating the site now so that Forward and men's are both more prominent on the site and easier to navigate between the two destinations. I mentioned the marketing that we're doing and more kind of cross-marketing between the two dedicated emails about Forward to that Revolve customer. This is more on Forward.

And then International. International is just shy of 20% of the business today. Over time we have -- again, number one is get the service and the product right. Service internationally involved making that international experience more like the US customer experience where it's free shipping, free returns. Historically, if you rewind five years ago, really painful for an international customer where you had to pay for your return. Not only did you have to pay for your return, but if you look at Canada, for example, you would be shocked at the checkout because you have these incremental Canadian taxes that you'd have to pay.

And then if you want to return the product, you need to go to the government to recollect those taxes. We wouldn't refund those taxes. So now with all-inclusive pricing, everything is included in the price on the website. Then if you return, you get the full price returned and refunded to you, and then we work with the Canadian government to recollect those taxes. So huge improvement in the customer experience. Of course, that does increase the return rate, but more than offset by the increase in gross sales, which increases the net sales. So that localization started in the UK, moved into Europe, moved into Australia. Canada was one of the more recent large -- larger markets to launch that all-inclusive pricing and localization.

Those western markets, the more established markets have been more challenged recently both from a macro perspective and then also from a currency perspective. We price in US dollar and then convert to the local currency. So when you have a strong US dollar, you add a pricing disadvantage to the tune of 10% plus or minus in those core regions like the UK and Europe, also Australia. So those regions being challenged, but offset by really great growth coming from some of our emerging regions like Mexico, China, Middle East, India. Mexico has doubled year-over-year and is now one of our top five markets.

And then looking ahead, internationally, it's all about that customer experience, number one; get the product right, number two, technology, site enhancement, payment types, and then we can really start to market to that international customer. Right now we are indirectly marketing. Social media really has no boundaries outside of maybe China, so -- and we have an international influencer base. So we are indirectly tapping into that international customer, but going in country by country and more dedicated and specific marketing to that customer to expand the share.

Own brands. Huge opportunity for us in the long run. If you look back kind of at the history of own brands, we went from zero to 36% in five years from 2014 to 2019. That was too fast. And we became over-assorted in certain categories and price points. And kind of V2 of the own brands is to grow that, but in a more moderate pace. And we think we can have a more profitable own brand business at a lower percentage of net sales than we did before.

And that's going to come through a combination of new brands; also new styles and products within the existing brands expanding into additional categories. One of the recent categories was Wellbeing + Beingwell, which is a sustainable, active brand that we launched. And then also partnering with influencers, celebrities, personalities. If you think about Helsa, recent launch that has performed very well, and unique from our own brand perspective in that Helsa was carried on both Forward and Revolve, kind of edited differently for each of those sites, but the product was similar. So a really great launch, and then I mentioned LOBA, which was a recent launch, performing really well and really tapping more into that younger GenZ consumer versus the millennial that's been at the core.

And that is a wrap.

Questions And Answers

Dylan Carden:

So we have about eight minutes here. We have a Q&A breakout at [indecipherable] on the Midwest. But if anyone has questions now, happy to fill them.

Unidentified Participant:

[indecipherable] anything about going into France or outside [indecipherable]

Jesse Timmermans:

Mostly outside. I think at some point -- sorry, the question was for beauty, can we expand with own brands or is it going to be kind of third-party outside brands. At least for the start, outside third-party brands and really building out that assortment. Then over time, there is the potential for own brands, but not a focus in the near term.

Dylan Carden:

This idea of you kind of capturing more than beyond festivals, events, something that Michael talks about increasingly, I guess broadly, what's the strategy there and sort of what have you seen from a market share or a wallet share perspective of your existing customer base? And do you look at Nordstrom's 35 million customers and say those are our customers hopefully over time? Is that sort of the basic transition that you are expecting? Yeah, yeah. Absolutely. So yeah, we see those 35 million customers as very addressable and we continue to take share and then you add Nordstrom plus Macy's plus Saks plus Neiman plus everybody else. We think we can continue to take share, and again, largely addressable when we expand categories, when we expand age/demographics. So that is the goal both in that core customer, address more aspects of her wallet. Beauty, for example, is a great way to acquire new customers. New customers over-index on beauty versus the other. So it's a great price point to get her; also a great add-on product if she's buying the dress to throw in a beauty product. And then I mentioned the men's where 30% to 50% of the male purchases out there come from a female. We have this very captive and active female audience. So tapping into that. And then just the other adjacent categories. Cold weather gear, for example, historically, it's been all about -- not all about, but skewed towards summer, spring, the festival, the dresses, the swim, the going out. Two years ago, we started to push more on ski and ski wear. So that really curated, aspirational, going to Aspen, Vail, Switzerland, and really kind of looking your best while you're in the lodge, while you're skiing, and that's performed really well over the last couple of years. So more opportunity to spread the sales out across the year, tap into more aspects of her wallet and expand the TAM via some of those other demographics. And what was a bit of a different messaging, right? I mean, I think some people say, oh, Instagram is losing its appeal or Facebook [indecipherable] but as TikTok and other platforms emerge, it actually benefits strategy as far as being able to reach a broader audience [indecipherable] Yeah, yeah. Absolutely. We feel -- we are around for 20 years. So we were around before Instagram, before Facebook. So there's -- she's always looked to somebody, something, some influencer to guide her in her purchase, whether that was kind of the fashion editor in the early days, that moved to bloggers, that moved to influencers on Instagram with a static post that shifted now more recently to video, whether video being on Instagram or on TikTok. So we've been able to really navigate and be at the forefront of all of those shifts. And like I said, she'll always look to something or somebody for that influence. So we're confident that we can continue to shift where she's at, will be at, and will be, I think, the key is being authentic, having the right merchandise, combined with the right marketing, whatever kind of venue or vehicle that's in. AI, I had mentioned in the early kind of part of the presentation, that being an AI-generated image. And that kind of permeates throughout the organization and throughout the growth strategies. We think AI is real, it's here. We've been using AI/machine learning for years, whether that's through in early days of kind of inventory planning, inventory management. That moved more recently, in the last couple of years, to operational things like fraud detection, lost package, prediction. And now more recently, that AI editorial campaigns, this kind of feeds into how you can kind of shift the marketing, shift the messaging, shift the product in a really quick way. So that AI image, it was a campaign, multiple models, AI generated. With clothing, we actually took that clothing that was produced via AI and produced physical goods and sold that via our own brand platform to real customers. So that's the next step, is using AI for editorial, for creative, for next step design and just the speed of iteration that we can accomplish through AI versus the traditional processes, we're pretty excited about. And then longer term, the site experience and I mentioned return rate increasing. We are looking to decrease return rate, but in win-win ways for the customer and for us. We're not going to make it harder for her and start charging for returns, shortening the window, pulling the return slip from the package. We know that if you do some of those things, return rate will increase, but it also is a negative experience for her and will impact that long-term retention that we're proud of, and that benefits us over the long term. So are there ways via technology, via AI to improve the experience for her on the site through personalization, recommendations? That's more near term. Longer term is there, augmented reality, AI-generated kind of virtual try-on to make that first purchase more educated. I think there will always be the case where she's going to an event on Saturday, she needs a dress, she's going to buy five to make sure she gets the right one for that event. And we're okay with that. But it's just making that experience better and better for her. And to the extent we can't reduce the return rate, she continues to behave in that way and by the multiple dresses to keep that one. Then offset that with cost and efficiency improvements through East Coast distribution center, through better inventory kind of flows, and a number of other projects where we're working on. When you refer to active customers, is that all individuals or you have [indecipherable]

Jesse Timmermans:

No, all individuals. Yeah, yeah. It's -- yeah, you mentioned [indecipherable]. It's all purchases and returns and individual customers, but we do have a sizable reverse logistics process given that if our $1 billion of sales and we have a 50% plus return rates, we're actually selling $2 billion to get $1 billion return to net to that $1 billion. So it's a pretty scaled operation.

Dylan Carden:

[indecipherable] one minute, how you're managing costs.

Jesse Timmermans:

One minute, managing costs.

Dylan Carden:

From a marketing standpoint. [indecipherable] marketing stand, and then yeah, you mentioned sort of the [indecipherable]

Jesse Timmermans:

Yeah, yeah, yeah. We -- number one, the premium price point helps, especially on that return rate, where you have more room to absorb the cost of the returns versus operating at a lower price point, you're paying the same cost per package going in and out. So that's a benefit for us. And really, a moat is that premium price point, the premium nature of the product.

The areas we are focused on controlling cost, I guess, one is gross margin, working through that inventory, getting back to a higher full-price mix. We're confident in that, we're confident we can do that in the near term. If you work down the P&L, the fulfillment line item. I mentioned East Coast distribution center. That is very early on, early innings. So as we grow into that space, scale efficiencies, and then also cost benefit from not shipping onesie, twosie products back and forth from the East Coast to the West Coast, but re-fulfilling within the East Coast. That also impacts the selling and distribution line item where you're offsetting that kind of the return rate with those freight savings and not shipping back and forth.

Next step on the fulfillment footprint is looking at international distribution centers, small footprint international distribution centers to do that refulfillment where we're holding the returns in the region and reshipping to that customer in the region. And then we have probably two dozen other individual initiatives against that selling and distribution line item from looking at the international freight carriers and using alternative carriers, optimizing rates within existing carriers, domestically looking at line haul opportunities and different last-mile carriers to get better freight rates there.

We're also seeing fuel surcharge start to abate. So that was a peak last Q2. We're starting to see a tailwind from that versus a headwind that we've been seeing for the last several years.

Marketing is one where we are not calling that a cost savings. With the strong balance sheet, with the strong customer that we have, we want to continue to -- market continue to acquire customers. While others are pulling back and forced to play defense, we think this is a great opportunity to really build for the future and come out stronger when we get through this cycle.

And then G&A, being around for 20 years, that's largely fixed, and we get scale efficiencies on that line item over time. And this is, again, an opportunity for us. When others are pulling back and, for example, firing engineers, we're hiring engineers. We're going more global with our technology and back office infrastructure. So a lot of opportunity in these kind of disjointed times.

Dylan Carden:

[indecipherable]

Jesse Timmermans:

Thanks, Dylan.

urn:contentItem:63BV-CRS1-JDKC-R472-00000-00SCARFACE FIRE UPDATE AUG. 102021-08-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:09:08ZLexisNexisSCARFACE FIRE UPDATE AUG. 10

SALMON, Idaho, Aug. 10 -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture's U.S. Forest Service unit - Salmon-Challis National Forest - issued the following press release:

The Central Idaho Dispatch Zone is at VERY HIGH Fire Danger

CENTRAL IDAHO FIRE RESTRICTIONS AREA IS IN STAGE I FIRE RESTRICTIONS

Fire will be updated as significant activity occurs

Date of Detection: August 7, 2021

Current Size: 292 acres

Location: 2 and half miles southeast of the Middle Fork Lodge; Middle Fork Ranger District; Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness

Cause: Lightning/Natural

Fuels: grass, brush, snags with a heavy dead and down fuel component in the 1979 Mortar Creek Fire scar

On the evening of August 7, eight (8) firefighters were flown out to the fire which was estimated to be three to six acres in size. Due to night fall and the steep rugged terrain firefighters began initial attack first thing the morning on August 8. A cold front that day produced sustained windspeeds of 30-40 mph on the fire, which increased fire activity resulting in the fire growing to approximately 250 acres. Helicopters were unable to fly and drop water on the fire due to the winds. Additionally, due to safety concerns which included numerous snags and very active fire behavior, the firefighters disengaged from the fire.

Following the cold front event, two (2) Type 1 crews (20 people) and a Type I helicopter have been assigned to the fire. Crews are beginning by working to secure the Middle Fork corridor, and then will move to complete containment lines around the fire perimeter. The helicopter will make water drops on the fire to help slow the spread of the fire and strengthen containment lines.

In addition to the full suppression actions, Forest Fire Managers have also inserted one (1) Wildland Fire Modules (10 people) at Thomas Creek Airstrip to begin evaluating values at risk which are defined as property, structures, physical improvements, natural and cultural resources, community infrastructure, and economic, environmental, and social values such as the Middle Fork River corridor. This work includes evaluations and an appropriate level of preparatory work for defense of the identified values to initiate a point protection strategy if needed due to fire behavior.

WEATHER: High pressure ridge aloft will move over Idaho and expect dry and warm conditions through Friday. Winds are expected to be lighter on Wednesday as the ridge axis moves closer but areas of afternoon 10 to 20 mph gusts will still be present. The next chance for showers and thunderstorms will be Saturday mainly in zone 476 then become much more widespread Sunday into next Tuesday. Will have potential for significant wind increase Monday with cold frontal passage.

CLOSURES AND RESTRICTIONS: No closures are in place for the Scarface Fire. If you are recreating near an ongoing wildfire suppression operation, please keep your distance - do not congregate in the area and allow the firefighters to do their job safely and efficiently.

Forest officials are asking the public to be extremely careful when recreating on the Forest. The 2021 fire season has begun with unseasonably high temperatures and low fuel moistures, so it's especially imperative this year for the public to be aware of the very high fire danger and Stage 1 Fire Restriction for the entire Salmon-Challis National Forest, excluding the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness. We can all make a difference in reducing human-caused fires during this season. Remember, One Less Spark Means One Less Wildfire.

Nationally, there are 96 uncontained large fires being managed under a full suppression strategy and 52 large fires managed under a strategy other than full suppression. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com

urn:contentItem:618D-JKH1-JCBF-S1X4-00000-00NEWSROOM: TEXAS AANDM FOREST SERVICE EMPLOYEE EARNS GOLD SMOKEY BEAR AWARD2020-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:09:08ZLexisNexisNEWSROOM: TEXAS AANDM FOREST SERVICE EMPLOYEE EARNS GOLD SMOKEY BEAR AWARDStates News ServiceCOLLEGE STATION, TX

The following information was released by the Texas Forest Service (TFS):

Karen Stafford, Wildfire Prevention Program Coordinator with Texas AandM Forest Service is one of the members on a national team that has earned the Gold Smokey Bear Award.

The National Smokey Bear 75th Planning Team planned and executed a year-long celebration of Smokey Bear's 75th birthday in 2019.

The nation-wide celebration kicked off with the Tournament of Roses Parade on January 1, 2019 in Pasadena, California, and concluded in December 2019 with the Secretary of Agriculture's Christmas Tree lighting in Washington, D.C.

Other major events throughout the year included the development of an exhibit at Smokey's former enclosure at the National Zoo, a nation-wide distance learning opportunity (Smokey Bear LIVE), the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, an August 9th Time Square appearance, New York Times crossword puzzle and Jeopardy! mentions and more than 300 birthday parties across the country.

The team included members from the USDA Forest Service, the National Association of State Foresters and the Ad Council and in an innovative value-added approach also included a representative (Stafford) from State and Private Forestry to represent state forestry agencies.

"When you look at the numbers of wildfires and acres burned in this state and across the country, fire prevention must remain at the forefront of our minds. We simply could not prevent and fight these fires without the critical partnerships from our neighboring state and private landowners," said Jan Davis, Deputy Regional Forester for USDA Forest Service.

Davis, a former Texas AandM Forest Service employee herself, presented Stafford with the Smokey Bear Award in College Station Tuesday as part of the Texas AandM Forest Service's annual personnel meeting.

The Gold Smokey Bear Award is the highest honor given to organizations or individuals for outstanding wildfire prevention service that is national in scope over at least a two-year period. A maximum of three Gold Smokey Bear awards may be given annually.

The USDA Forest Service, the National Association of State Foresters (NASF) and the Advertising Council (through the Cooperative Forest Fire Prevention (CFFP) Program) sponsor the national Smokey Bear Awards.

urn:contentItem:62W6-B0B1-DY68-139K-00000-00USPS Issues Emergency Suspension of Post Office Locations as Telegraph Wildfire Spreads2021-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:09:08ZLexisNexisUSPS Issues Emergency Suspension of Post Office Locations as Telegraph Wildfire SpreadsAila Slisco

"The Postal Service will do everything possible to provide service to the community while emphasizing the safety of our employees and customers as our first priority," USPS spokesperson Rod Spurgeon told Newsweek in a statement.

Arizona's Telegraph wildfire continued to spread on Tuesday, prompting the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) to temporarily shut down multiple locations.

The fire, which was first reported on Friday, had burned approximately 71,756 acres as of Tuesday afternoon, according to the InciWeb wildfire information system. The fire has not been contained. Less than 50 miles away, the Mescal wildfire also continued to grow, with approximately 65,825 acres burning after fire crews contained 23 percent of the blaze.

Emergency suspensions of nearby post offices were issued in response to the growing infernos. All business normally conducted at post offices in Globe, Miami and Claypool was redirected to Payson until further notice. The Safford post office was temporarily handling business from the San Carlos, Bylas and Peridot offices.

Customers picking up their mail at alternate post offices will be required to present valid picture IDs during normal business hours. A USPS release noted that the closures are temporary and further details "will be provided as they become available regarding the reopening of these offices."

"The Postal Service will do everything possible to provide service to the community while emphasizing the safety of our employees and customers as our first priority," USPS spokesperson Rod Spurgeon told Newsweek in a statement.

Incident Commander Dave Bales described the Telegraph blaze as "active and aggressive" on Tuesday, with gusts of winds helping the fire spread to the northeast. Crews of at least 741 people were working to establish fire lines and scout for natural barriers and roads that could be used to contain the fire.

Residents of Oak Flat Campground and Top-of-the-World were evacuated over the weekend. Residents of the Miami area were also told to evacuate, while those in Superior, Globe and Claypool were asked to prepare to evacuate.

Crews of at least 659 people were working to contain the Mescal fire, which was first reported last Tuesday. Residents of areas including Coyote Flats, Soda Canyon and El Capitan were told to evacuate as the fire spread.

Some previously evacuated residents were allowed to return home by Tuesday under the condition that they should be prepared for the possibility of another evacuation. Residents of San Carlos and Peridot were also told to prepare for evacuations.

U.S. Route 60 between Superior and Miami, State Route 77 between Globe and Winkelman, and State Route 177 between Superior and Winkelman were closed due to the wildfires, according to the Arizona Department of Transportation. U.S. Route 70 was closed to semi-trucks and commercial transportation between milepost 272 and 302.

The exact causes of both fires remain under investigation, although a human cause has already been determined for the Telegraph fire. Officials estimate that the Telegraph fire will be fully contained by June 20, while the Mescal fire is expected to be contained by June 30.

NCLA Amicus Brief Challenges Supreme Court to Deep-Six Chevron Deference and at-Sea Monitor Rule

Washington, DC (July 24, 2023) — Today, the New Civil Liberties Alliance filed an amicus curiae brief calling on the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn its destructive Chevron precedent in Loper Bright Enterprises, et al. v. Gina Raimondo, et al. The brief also asks the Court to set aside a rule promulgated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the National Marine Fisheries Service (NOAA Fisheries).

The agencies' Final Rule requires fishing companies to pay for government monitoring of their herring catch, but no statute authorizes the agencies to obtain funding from regulated parties. Nevertheless, in August 2022, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit invoked the Chevron precedent in Loper Bright v. Raimondo, ruling that NOAA Fisheries' Final Rule was allowable under an expansive reading of the Magnuson-Stevens Act. Chevron requires federal judges to defer to federal agencies' reasonable interpretations of ambiguous statutes.

Decade's Lowest Birth Rate Recorded in Germany Amid Changing Demographic Landscape

Germany experiences the smallest birth rate in ten years, as revealed by the Federal Statistical Office's recent data. In the past year, a mere 738,819 newborns were recorded, marking a decrease of 56,673, or seven percent, compared to the previous year.

The record birth rate since 1997 was documented in 2021, with 795,492 births, an occurrence many Germans attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic, leading to a surge in what was often referred to as 'corona babies.' However, in 2022, the birth rate dropped by eight percent to 1.46 children per woman, the lowest since 2013. This figure had increased significantly in 2021, to 1.58 children per woman.

To prevent a population decrease in developed nations without relying on immigration, the Statistical Office states that an average of 2.1 children should be born per woman. Despite the low birth rate, Germany's population saw an impressive rise last year to 84.3 million due to record levels of immigration. Netherlands: Friend or Foe? an Interview With Thierry Baudet

'Politics,' Bismarck famously said, 'is the art of the possible.' But when we've lost everything and are only allowed to speak within the little bit of space allotted by the mainstream, then it is time for the Right to re-group and re-think its tactics. Whatever it is we have been doing for the past decades, it simply has not worked. Could it be because conservatives are, in fact, more concerned about being accepted by the mainstream establishment—that is, by our enemies—than building a broad coalition to resist it?

The Left never disavows its own radicals or their ideas; instead, it tries to 'mainstream' those radical ideas—precisely because it is aware that radicals are its most effective, most powerful shock troops. In contrast, conservatives routinely push away all those to their right. But why is the fear of being denounced by their opponents—including the mainstream media—so prevalent among conservatives?

Such questions led me recently to sit down with various controversial intellectuals, including the founder and leader of the Forum for Democracy (FVD) party in the Netherlands, Thierry Baudet. After writing his Ph.D. under the supervision of Roger Scruton, he acquired international fame in 2019 when his party topped the polls in senate elections. Since then, his reputation has suffered after making controversial and impolitic statements, while his political fortunes have become uncertain. Despite many warnings, I chose to catch up with him at last year's FVD Party Congress, as well as afterward, for the following wide-ranging conversation.

Nine EU Countries Have Still Not Received Any Money From the COVID-19 Recovery Fund

As many as nine EU member states have yet to receive a cent from the Recovery Fund created by the European Union to provide financial aid to countries following the coronavirus pandemic.

The Recovery Fund was supposed to be a quick injection of funding for EU economies in the aftermath of the pandemic; however, just €150 billion of the €800 billion aid package has been distributed across the bloc to date, reaching just 18 countries.

Poland Will No Longer Sell Energy Drinks to Minors

Starting from January 1, 2024, individuals under the age of 18 will be prohibited from purchasing energy drinks. This decision was approved by the Sejm (the lower house of the Polish Parliament). The bill has now been forwarded to the Senate for consideration.

The approved law entails a complete ban on selling drinks containing taurine and caffeine to individuals under 18 years old. This applies to energy drinks and beverages containing caffeine in excess of 150 mcg/L or taurine, with the exception of substances naturally present in these drinks. The ban on selling energy drinks to teenagers and children received the support of 278 deputies.

Romania and Slovakia Lodge Complaints Against Orban's Speech Referring to 'Territories Torn From Hungary'

Romania and Slovakia have lodged diplomatic protests against Hungary following Prime Minister Viktor Orban's speech in Tusnadfürdo, Transylvania, on July 22.

This comes freshly on the heels of similar protests from Czechia Prime Minister Petr Fiala, who issued a response to Orban after the Hungarian leader accused Czechia of abandoning the Visegrad Group and getting into bed with the EU federalists.

Seven Years on, Jury to Deliver Verdict on Brussels ISIS Terror Attack That Killed 32

BRUSSELS (AP) — A jury is expected to render its verdict Tuesday over Belgium's deadliest peacetime attack, suicide bombings at the Brussels airport and a busy subway station in 2016 that killed 32 people in a wave of violence in Europe claimed by the Islamic State group.

Among the 10 defendants is Salah Abdeslam, who already is serving a life sentence without parole in France over his role in attacks that hit Paris cafes, the Bataclan theater and France's national stadium in 2015. The suspects in Brussels were tried on charges including murder, attempted murder and participation in the acts of a terrorist group.

Sweden Gains Shrine to Mary, Mother of Persecuted Christians

Sweden's Cardinal Anders Arborelius dedicated the country's first shrine Saturday specifically for prayer for persecuted Christians.

The Archbishop of Stockholm presided at the ceremony July 22 at the Holy Martyrs Syriac Catholic Church in Kista, a district in northern Stockholm.

The Fires in Greece Are More Likely to Have Been Caused by Arsonists Than Global Warming

Ross Clark has written a good piece for the Spectator 's Coffee House blog pointing out that 2023 has not been an unusually bad year for forest fires in Europe and, according to Nasa satellite date, the number of forest fires globally actually fell by about 25% between 2001 and 2015.

UK Ministry of Justice Invests in Social Listening Tool

The UK's Ministry of Justice (MoJ) has decided to spend taxpayer money in order to be able to use a monitoring tool whose job is to access people's conversations that might impact the ministry's 'reputation.'

This decision certainly impacts that reputation, but perhaps not in a positive aspect.

And it would be an interesting full circle if the maker of the software, Brandwatch (owned by Cision, a PR outfit) — allowed the MoJ to learn how inking this three-year deal will impact its reputation.

UK: Death of Family: Half of Children Not Living With Both Parents by 14

A study from the Marriage Foundation suggested that nearly half of children in Britain are no longer living with both of their biological parents by the time they reach 14 years of age.

Drawing on a dataset of 4,476 first-born children in the UK conducted by the Millennium Cohort Study and weighing the sample to represent the national population, the Marriage Foundation revealed on Monday that 46 per cent of children in the country are not living with both their natural parents by the age of 14.

UK: Farage Vows to Uncover the Truth About Banking Scandal

Nigel Farage has vowed to uncover the 'absolute truth' about how the BBC obtained 'dodgy' information about his bank account at the British private bank, Coutts. Speaking to GB News, the former leader of the UK Independence Party (UKIP) said British citizens deserve to know the truth about the machinations of the NatWest Group, the holding company which owns Coutts, 'not just because NatWest has 19 million customers,' but also 'because we bailed them out after their greed and stupidity back in 2008.'

UK: Just Stop Oil Hits Back After Criticism From Met Over Policing Cost: 'We Will Not Die Quietly'

Police say a 13-week campaign by Just Stop Oil has cost them more than 7.7 million, as a senior Met officer decried their actions as more crime than protest.

But the anti-fossil fuel climate action group has hit back — saying his comments were a clear indication legitimate protest was now being treated like a crime.

UK: Meta's Nick Clegg Brags About Censoring 'Election Misinformation'

After the short lull in the US presidential campaign (it never really stops, but happens with varying intensity), campaigning is already starting to pick up speed ahead of the 2024 election, and Facebook looks like it wants to preemptively convince the powers-that-be that it is playing ball, censorship-wise.

(They call it, 'fighting misinformation.')

Former UK politician turned Big Tech exec, Meta (Facebook) Global Affairs President Nick Clegg, last week attended one of those meetings between the White House and Meta, Microsoft, Google, and Amazon. The conversation was reportedly about artificial intelligence and how scary that is in terms of 'undermining elections' — but Clegg's statements made afterwards suggest he was eager to address some broader issues here.

Watch: Hundreds of 'Youths' Terrorize UK Town Center

A town center in England was plunged into chaos when hundreds of 'youths' terrorized pedestrians and businesses on the final day of school last week, according to reports.

The shocking events unfolded on Friday afternoon in Watford, located near the outskirts of Greater London.

Algeria Applies to BRICS Ahead of Planned Summit

After agreeing last week to strengthen cooperation with China in security, national defense, and other areas, Algeria, North Africa's second-largest economy, has submitted an application to join the BRICS group and a request to become a shareholder member of the BRICS New Development Bank (NDB) with $1.5 billion.

The move, which comes roughly a month ahead of the 15th annual BRICS summit set to take place in Johannesburg, South Africa, highlights the North African country's geopolitical and economic reorientation toward Russia and China as it appears to wish, at least in part, to decouple itself from the collective West.

During a state visit to Moscow last month, Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune and President Putin agreed to strengthen the 'strategic partnership' between their two countries.

Chaos Erupts as Protesters Block Roads, Clash With Police After Judicial Law Passes

Activists raging against the government's passage of the first part of its plan to remake the judiciary faced off against police for hours in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem Monday night, blocking freeways and promising to ratchet up demonstrations, as lawmakers vowed to push ahead with the rest of the contentious program.

Using mounted police and water cannons, authorities only managed to clear the major Tel Aviv thoroughfare after 1 a.m., though thousands continued to demonstrate at nearby Kaplan junction, where some 15,000 had massed hours earlier in reaction to the government coalition's contentious 'reasonableness' bill being approved on its final two votes.

In Jerusalem, police also used officers on horseback and powerful blasts of skunk water to drive off protesters who rallied first outside the Knesset and later blocked the Begin freeway and demonstrated near the Supreme Court building, an institution that government critics say will be left toothless by the judicial overhaul, rending Israel's democracy defunct.

Hundreds Attempt to Storm Iraqi 'Green Zone' After Danish Quran-Burning Protest

Iraq's capital Baghdad has seen its second major protest against Western interests in just a few days as hundreds of people attempted to storm the Green Zone, an area of the city which houses several embassies, including the Danish embassy, as well as the Iraqi parliament.

The attempted storming, which saw security forces deploy tear gas and batons to repel the few protestors who managed to actually enter the area, took place over the weekend on Saturday, July 22nd, and was in reaction to the burning of a copy of the Islamic holy book, the Quran in Copenhagen, Denmark, the day prior, the Associated Press reports.

Russia Makes Digital Ruble Official

Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a law on Monday that introduces a digital ruble.

According to the document published on the official government portal, the electronic currency will become operational on August 1.

Russian Real Wages Growing in Double Digits — Putin

Russia is expected to demonstrate at least 2% GDP growth this year, alleviating the shrinking it experienced in 2022, President Vladimir Putin has said. Moreover, the real wages of the country's citizens have recently seen double-digit growth, he said.

The president made the remarks on Tuesday during a meeting with top officials to discuss the country's economy and issues it has been facing. Sectors such as manufacturing, retail, and construction have been demonstrating steady growth lately, Putin stated.

'Growth in these sectors, as well as a whole range of measures to support the economy, has had a positive effect on the state of the labor market,' he said.

'Unemployment rates are declining — now it is 3.2%. At the same time, real wages grew at double-digit rates for the first time since 2018 — for instance, by more than 10% in April,' he added.

Given the positive trends in Russia's economy, the country is expected to demonstrate GDP growth of at least 2%, Putin said. The growth will alleviate the losses Russia suffered last year, when its GDP shrank by 2.1%, the president noted.

The shrinking came amid multiple waves of anti-Russian sanctions, rolled out by the collective West in the wake of the conflict between Moscow and Kiev.

In the first five months of this year, Russian GDP already rose by 0.5%. Still, the country's economy remains in need of additional support, and an increase in state debt is also expected. The government believes additional borrowing is necessary, but it will work to contain the debt level to under 20% of GDP, according to Russian Deputy Finance Minister Irina Okladnikova.

'Generally, we now have a level of debt at 22.8 trillion rubles ($251 billion) — this is 14.9% of GDP. This is our safe boundary, although we realize that, in the current situation, we will be forced to raise it. We will have to do it, because our expenditures are growing,' Okladnikova said last week during a meeting of the Federation Council Committee on Budget and Financial Markets.

Ukraine Bans Poultry Imports From Poland After First Outbreak of Newcastle Disease in 50 Years

Ukraine has introduced a total ban on the import of poultry from Poland after Newcastle disease was detected in Polish chickens for the first time in 50 years.

The dangerous bird disease is causing legitimate concerns among Polish poultry producers, and although the disease was only identified in the northeastern Podlaskie region, there has been a negative impact on the entire Polish market, especially on exports to neighboring countries.

Ukraine's ban will have a devastating effect on the country's poultry market. Kyiv is a very important market for Poland, with Ukraine importing tens of millions of chickens from Poland every year.

Ukrainian Tanks Are Running on Russian Oil Refined in Hungary and Turkey

Ukraine's tanks are increasingly running on oil that comes from Russia in what German newspaper Handelsblatt describes as a paradox of war.

According to the Ukrainian customs authority, Kyiv is importing more and more diesel from Hungary and Turkey, both countries that process oil from Russia to a large extent in their refineries.

Ukraine Latest: U.S. Military Aid for 1st Time Includes Black Hornet Spy Drone

The U.S. has announced $400 million in additional military aid for Ukraine, including air defense missiles, armored vehicles and small drones. The new aid package will include, for the first time, U.S.-supplied Black Hornet surveillance drones made by Teledyne FLIR Defense, part of Teledyne Technologies. The Norwegian-built mini drone is being used in Ukraine through donations by the British and Norwegian governments. The U.S. will also supply additional munitions for Patriot air defense systems and National Advanced Surface-to-Air Missile Systems (NASAMS), as well as Stinger anti-aircraft systems.

We Didn't Have Enough Men or Equipment and This Gave Russia Time to Dig in, Says Zelensky

The world wondered why the long-discussed Ukrainian Spring offensive didn't arrive until Summer, and now we know why, as Ukrainian President Zelensky says he simply didn't have the men or the equipment to launch it any earlier.

The Ukrainian counteroffensive didn't start when expected because 'frankly, we didn't have enough munitions, armaments, not enough brigades properly trained in these weapons' to do so, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky told the Aspen Security Forum on Friday.

Australian Rent Nightmare as International Student is Forced to 'Hot-Bed' Because of the Surging Cost of Living Driving Up Prices for a Room

Priyanka, 19, splits the monthly rent of $550 with a truckie. During the night the bed is hers, during the day he sleeps in it while she's at school.

Australia to Buy 20 C-130 Hercules From U.S. for $6.6 Billion

Australia said Monday it will buy 20 new C-130 Hercules from the United States in a 9.8 billion Australian dollar ($6.6 billion) deal.

Greenacre Triple Shooting: Three People Rushed to Hospital Marks Latest Attack in Southwest Sydney Suburb Terrorised by Stabbings and Kidnappings

Three people who were rushed to hospital after being gunned down in their cars are the latest victims in a region that's become notorious for stabbings and shootings.

Kellett Australia Boss Troy Kellett Could Have Been 'Pressured' to Help the AlbanianMafia Import Drugs Before Falling to His Death From Shipping Container at Outer Harbour Docklands in Adelaide

Police are investigating whether a man who died in an interstate shipping yard shortly after midnight was searching for drugs from the Albanian mafia.

Key Assange Supporter Says WikiLeaks Founder Could Cut Deal to Secure Freedom

London: One of federal parliament's leading supporters of Julian Assange says the WikiLeaks founder could cut a deal with prosecutors and plead guilty to 'whatever nonsense' necessary to secure his release from prison.

Labor MP Julian Hill, the member for Bruce, tried unsuccessfully to visit Assange in Belmarsh prison, where he has been held since 2019, during a private trip to Europe recently.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has directly lobbied US President Joe Biden for the Queenslander's release but has so far failed to secure it, and has hinted that Assange may have to accept a plea deal.

'The reality is that Australia cannot force the United States to [release Assange], and if they refuse, then no Australian should judge Mr Assange if he chooses to just cut a deal and end this matter,' said Hill.

'His health is deteriorating and if the US refuses to do the right thing and drop the charges then no one would think less of him for crossing his fingers and toes, pleading guilty to whatever nonsense he has to and getting the hell out of there.'

Hill, a member of a cross-party group of MPs who support Assange's release, also hit out at supporters who he sees as fixated on having Assange suffer as a martyr and continue to languish in prison as he faces extradition to the United States.

Live Maggots in Toddler's Nappy: Grim Allegations Emerge About Mother From Whyalla, South Australia, Charged With Neglecting Her 18-Month-Old Daughter

A mother from South Australia fronted court charged with criminal neglect after police allegedly found maggots writhing in her 18-month-old daughter's overflowing nappy.

Man Shot Outside Home in Broad Daylight in 'Targeted' Attack in Sydney's South West

A? man has been shot in a 'targeted' attack outside a south-west Sydney home by an unknown person in broad daylight.

NSW Police said there were reports of gunshots fired just before 10.30am on Wednesday on Narelle Crescent in Greenacre.?

When they got to the scene, a 31-year-old man was found with gunshot wounds.

?'It's understood the man was outside the home when he was approached by an unknown person and shot,' police said.

The man was treated by paramedics at the scene before being taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition.

?Police believe it was a targeted attack.?

Toyota Hilux and Ford Ranger Competition That's Set to Shake Up Australia

The supersized US imports have hit the Australian market by storm and are hitting the streets at rapidly growing rate, sparking debate among motorists.

Utopian Residential Pty Ltd: Victorian Building Company Collapses Owing $3.2m to Tradies and the Tax Office

The Victorian-based company owes $3.2m to creditors, including $550,000 to the Australian Tax Office

Why This Run-Down Suburban House 'That Looks Like a Toilet' Sold for $1.15million at Guildford in Sydney's West

The four-bedroom house on Grassmere Street at Guildford, in Sydney's west, went under the hammer over the weekend, with a large crowd turning out for the auction.

Asylum Applications by Young, Muslim Men Soar in Germany, Surpassing Last Year by 78%

Germany experienced a dramatic rise in asylum applications in the first six months of the year, with a significant increase over the figure recorded for the same period last year.

According to the biannual report from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF), a total of 162,271 migrants applied for asylum in Germany from January to June, up 77.5 percent from the 84,583 applications made in the first six months of 2022.

Germany recorded 244,132 asylum applications in all of 2022, and 190,816 in 2021, suggesting this year's figure will far exceed the figures the country has experienced in the post-pandemic years.

Federal Judge Blocks Key Biden Admin Asylum Rule at Core of Post-Title 42 Strategy

The Biden administration was dealt a major blow in its efforts to control the ongoing border crisis on Tuesday when a federal judge blocked a rule introduced in May that makes migrants ineligible for asylum if they have entered illegally and failed to take advantage of expanded lawful pathways set up by the federal government.

In Germany the Migration Crisis of 2015-2016 May be Repeated

The report for the first half of the year from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) suggests that Germany may face a migration crisis similar to the one experienced in 2015-2016.

During January to June 2023, Germany received 162,271 asylum applications, of which 150,166 were first-time applications. The number of first-time applications has increased by 77.5% compared to the same period in 2022. By the end of 2023, the total number of applications could reach 324,000, approaching the levels seen during the 2015 crisis.

Currently, the majority of new applications come from citizens of Syria (29%), Afghanistan (18.2%), and Turkey (12.8%). Georgia ranks sixth (3.4%), and Russia is seventh (2.8%) in terms of asylum applications. Approximately 71.6% of all applications are filed by men under the age of 30. The majority of refugees aim to settle in the more prosperous federal states of Bavaria and North Rhine-Westphalia.

The police union in Germany, according to BILD, stated that these figures indicate a 'complete failure' of the current government's migration policy.

Italy: Meloni Conference Advises Aid, Alliances to STEM Migration Flow

A major conference on migration was held in Rome on Sunday, July 23rd at the initiative of Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni who, inspired by the recent agreement signed between Tunisia and the European Union, wants to extend the model to other countries around the Mediterranean.

Around twenty leaders from Mediterranean and African countries attended the conference in Italy. They were joined by Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, President of the European Council.

Discussions focused on ways of limiting illegal immigration into Europe and better managing legal immigration based on cooperation between states. The conference was also an opportunity for Meloni to reaffirm Italy's international stature: 'We are a bridge between EU, Africa, and the Middle East', she explained during the conference.

Lawyers Charging 10,000 to Make Fake Asylum Claims: Special Investigation Exposes Staff at Immigration Law Firms Briefing Clients on How to Lie to the Authorities to Win the Right to Stay in Britain

Lawyers are charging thousands of pounds to submit false asylum and human rights claims for illegal immigrants.

Staff at solicitors' firms readily agreed to help an undercover Mail reporter posing as an economic migrant get refugee status.

This was despite being told he had no legitimate reason to stay in the UK after arriving on a small boat.

Matt Gaetz Proposes Bill to End Birthright Citizenship for Children of Illegal Immigrants

On Tuesday, Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL) announced that he would be introducing legislation aimed at preventing children of illegal immigrants from automatically receiving citizenship simply for being born in the United States.

Every year in the United States, nearly 400,000 'anchor babies' are born and automatically declared American.

Poll: 83% of Democrats Deny There's Any Border Crisis

A Gallup poll has revealed that a massive 83 percent of Democratic voters deny that there is any border crisis in the U.S. despite more than 7 million illegal immigrants being encountered since Joe Biden took office.

The poll notes that only 17% of Democrats believe there's currently a crisis at the southwest border, a huge 20 point drop on figures recorded in 2019.

Smugglers Detained in Hungary Attempting to Transport 29 Illegal Migrants Across the Border

The National Tax and Customs Administration (NAV) reported on the arrest of two foreign citizens who tried to transport 29 illegal migrants to Italy in a truck through the Zala County region in southwestern Hungary. A Romanian and a Greek had hidden four women and 25 men among furniture and boxes, deceiving the inspecting officers by claiming to be carrying their personal belongings.

The situation became critical for the migrants as they were overloaded and suffocating in the overheated cargo compartment. According to NAV, the migrants, who stated they were from Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and India, 'could not have survived the journey to its end.' After apprehending the smugglers and migrants, they were handed over to the Zala County police.

The Number of Illegal Migrants in the US Exceeds the Population of 35 States in Three Years

After the number of illegal immigrants entering the United States in the last three years surpassed the 7 million mark, President Joe Biden's administration decided to file a lawsuit against Governor Greg Abbott of Texas, accusing him of insufficiently securing the country's southern border with Mexico. Under the watch of Joe Biden, more than 7 million illegal immigrants entered the USA.

UK: 'Find a Girl, Arrange a Marriage': How Solicitors Told an Undercover Reporter How to Cheat the Asylum System — With One Even Appearing to Offer Their Daughters as Potential Spouses

Lawyers helping conjure up fake asylum claims are telling migrants to find themselves a wife as a loophole around immigration controls, the Mail investigation uncovered.

Solicitors told an undercover reporter posing as an economic migrant to apply for asylum and then 'find a girl, arrange a marriage' to 'anyone who has permanent residence here'.

One even offered to play matchmaker, mentioning a client who had two daughters that could be prospective spouses.

Affirmative Action Battle Moves on to the Military

by Daniel Greenfield

One of the Biden administration's big arguments for racially discriminating against white and Asian students in college admissions was the need for military diversity. More than half of the 'national interest' section in its amicus brief argued that the military 'depends on a well-qualified and diverse officer corps' which requires that colleges select for diversity over merit.

'It is not possible to achieve that diversity without race-conscious admissions, including at the nation's service academies,' Solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar told the Supreme Court.

The Roberts decision in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard shot down affirmative action as a legal practice, but punted on the question of racial discrimination within the military and its service branch academies. A footnote briefly stated that, 'no military academy is a party to these cases, however, and none of the courts below addressed the propriety of race-based admissions systems in that context. This opinion also does not address the issue, in light of the potentially distinct interests that military academies may present.'

The idea that racial discrimination should be illegal at colleges, but still legal at service branch academies like the Air Force Academy and the Naval Academy, is a loophole. Justice Sotomayor argued that the exception proves that 'the Fourteenth Amendment does not categorically prohibit the use of race in college admissions.' And it's hard to deny her reasoning. Either racially discriminating against students is legal or it's illegal. National security can only go so far to justify an illegal practice especially when it's a social element with an indirect effect.

Democrats quickly attacked Justice Roberts for seemingly leaving the carveout on military diversity that the Biden administration had demanded as a matter of national security

Detransitioner Files $1m Lawsuit Against Doctors for Botched Mastectomy That Left Her 'Permanently Disfigured'

A 21-year-old Texas woman who detransitioned is suing a medical clinic and its doctors for 'gross malpractice' after she was put on puberty blockers at 17 and was pressured into a botched double mastectomy that she says left her 'permanently disfigured.'

Soren Aldaco offered an emotional recollection of her traumatic medical transition in an exclusive interview on 'The Ingraham Angle' Monday, revealing details of a $1 million lawsuit she filed last week against the doctors and a nurse practitioner who, according to the suit, pushed her to transition, 'irreversibly disfiguring and disabling' her with surgical mutilation while ignoring a host of mental health challenges she was struggling with at the time.

Elon Musk Warns Moviegoers About Woke 'Barbie' Movie: 'You Will Pass Out Before it Ends'

Twitter boss Elon Musk has slammed the new 'Barbie' movie and warned social media users about the film's 'woke' agenda.

Musk joined the chorus of critics who have panned the 'Barbie' movie.

In response to another user's Twitter post, Musk blasted the movie's incessant carping about the 'patriarchy.'

Panic!

They're saying, 'Heat is the new COVID.'

Manipulating data and spreading fear to coerce the population into mass compliance.

Yeah, the similarities are uncanny.

Putin Signs Law Banning Gender Reassignment

Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday signed a law banning gender reassignment in all cases except when allowed for health reasons.

The relevant document is published at the official legal information portal.

Temple U to Host Philly 'FatCon' With Queer Sex Therapist Offering 'Fat Positive Sexual Healthcare'

Temple University is set to host the first-ever Philly 'FatCon' this October, a conference boasting its role as an exclusively judgment-free fat-focused event featuring 'fat-friendly' fitness classes, vendors, talks with influencers, a Halloween costume party, and more.

'The Fat Sex Therapist' Sonalee Rashatwar, who uses they/he pronouns according to one of the con's Instagram posts, is slated to be the conference keynote speaker. Rashatwar commonly focuses on the 'White supremacist' ideals behind 'fatphobia,' the 'social construct' of health, 'fat trauma' and the intersection of fat and gender, according to their website.

'Based in Philly, they are a superfat queer bisexual non-binary therapist and co-founder of Radical Therapy Center, specialized in treating sexual trauma, diet trauma, racial or immigrant trauma, and South Asian family abuse, while offering fat positive sexual healthcare,' the post explains, adding that VIP ticket holders to the event will get the chance to meet and greet with Rashatwar.

UK: Trans Woman Who Blasted Hotel Spa for Not Giving Her a Key to Female Changing Rooms Sparks Furious Row With Critics Including Sharron Davies — and Demands Worker Who 'Assumed' She Would Use Unisex Facilities is Sent for Gender Sensitivity Training

Anne Coombes, 65, alleged a staff member at the Mercure Hotel spa in Sheffeld had 'assumed' that she wanted to use the unisex changing facilities

Link to the original story.
